Headline: Barron's(5/21) The Dividend Dearth: Still Too Stingy
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   Share the wealth! As corporations continue to favor share-repurchase programs as a way to boost stock prices, a small band of institutional investors and equity strategists are urging managements to focus more on an old-fashioned alternative: dividends.   They argue that corporations fail to recognize that dividends are increasingly popular with individual investors, and that ample payouts can be just as good -- or even better -- for stock prices than big buybacks.  Just look at some of the strongest sectors of the stock market in the past two years: electric utilities, real-estate investment trusts, cigarette makers, telecommunications providers and energy-oriented master limited partnerships. All of them pay nice dividends.   "A lot of corporations are missing the seismic shift in retail demand for yield," says Henry McVey, chief investment strategist at Morgan Stanley. As tens of millions of baby boomers start retirement, the demand for yield-oriented investments will climb. McVey notes that Americans over 65 have equity portfolios with an average yield of 2.6%, versus 0.8% for those under 65.   Over all, Corporate America remains stingy with dividends. Companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 index are expected to dole out just 30% of their earnings in dividends in 2007, a record-low profit payout.   The dividend yield on the S&P 500 is only 1.8%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average yields just a bit more: 2.1%. The S&P small- and mid-cap stock indexes yield only a bout 1%.   U.S companies have raised dividends at a double-digit rate in recent years, but operating earnings have been rising even more briskly. The S&P 500 payout ratio -- the percentage of earnings paid out to stockholders -- has been in a near-steady decline since the mid-1980s, when it stood at 55%. Prior to the early 1980s, buybacks were rare and companies took pride in their dividends, typically paying out more than half their profits.   In 1980, 94% of the companies in the S&P 500 paid dividends; now 77%, or 387, do. And of the 6,000 companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange, Nasdaq or American Stock Exchange that aren't in the S&P 500, just 40% pay dividends. Most technology companies, including such notables as Apple (ticker: AAPL), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Dell (DELL) and Oracle (ORCL) refuse to pay dividends, as do Amgen (AMGN), Berkshire Hathaway (BRK-A) and Viacom (VIA).   "Dividend initiations haven't grown the way I expected," says Howard Silverblatt, senior index analyst at Standard & Poor's. Silverblatt had figured that two events in 2003 would lead to more dividend payers. One was the cut in the top federal-tax rate on dividends to 15%, on par with the top rate on capital gains. The other was Microsoft's (MSFT) decision to start paying a dividend.   However, "tech companies looked at Microsoft and said the dividend hasn't done anything for its stock price. They decided they could do better with the money: buybacks," Silverblatt says. Now some companies are balking at paying or boosting payouts out of concern that the election of a Democratic president in 2008 could lead to an end to the favorable tax treatment of dividends.   One dividend fan, Edward von der Linde, the manager of the Lord Abbett Mid-Cap Value fund, says companies should pay them as a matter of principle: "Shareholders own the company. The earnings are their cash. Give it back." As for a potential rise in federal dividend taxes, von der Linde asks: "Since when is my tax status the business of management?"   He isn't crazy about share repurchases, arguing that they "give money to people who want to go away. Why not give the money to all shareholders equitably? The only way that the board of directors and management can directly affect shareholders is via the dividend." Von der Linde is frustrated that many companies employ sophisticated software -- and production tools like Six Sigma -- to run their businesses but have no coherent dividend policy.   Where can investors turn for yield? Among big companies, opportunities are scarce. Only three in the S&P 500 index yield more than 5%. Windstream (WIN) and Citizens Communications (CZN), two rural phone companies, offer over 6%, and Washington Mutual (WM), a big thrift whose significant mortgage exposure lately has worried Wall Street, yields 5.1%. Banks generally are generous with dividends. US Bancorp (USB), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) yield 4% or more. In the drug sector, Pfizer (PFE) is the leader with a 4.2% yield. Marlboro-maker Altria (MO) yields about 4%. Dividends of consumer companies Coca-Cola (KO), PepsiCo (PEP), Procter & Gamble (PG) and Colgate-Palmolive (CL) are in the 2% range.   Coke, PepsiCo, P&G, Altria and Bank of America are among an elite group that have boosted dividends for 25 straight years. Pepsi just lifted its dividend by 25%. Once-ample REIT dividend yields have shrunk with the stocks' multiyear advance; real-estate investment trusts now yield an average of 4% -- and those dividends carry no tax benefits.   Once a great source of dividends, U.S. energy companies have grown stingy as their profits have soared. Their average payout ratio is less than 20%. Setting the tone for the oil industry is ExxonMobil (XOM), which devotes much of its free cash flow to buybacks while yielding just 1.7%.   Foreign oil giants like BP (BP) and Royal Dutch Shell (RDS-B) are more forthcoming with dividends, now in the 4% range. In fact, European payout ratios generally are higher than those in the U.S. Plump dividends are available from Vodafone Group (VOD), Deutsche Telekom (DT), HSBC (HBC) and British American Tobacco (BTI). All boast yields in the 4% to 5% range.   The waning importance of dividends in the States reflects the rise in the past two decades of institutional investors, who tend to see stocks as vehicles for capital gains, not income. Historically, however, dividends have been crucial to investors. Since 1928, stocks have returned 10.4% annually, with 40% of that generated by dividends.   One of the drawbacks of investing through mutual funds rather than directly is that fund fees eat into dividend yields. Most stock funds outside the equity-income area yield 1% or less. Dividend-oriented funds like the WisdomTree exchange-traded funds have proven popular, with WisdomTree attracting over $3 billion in assets in less than a year.   Given the strength of corporate balance sheets and overall profits, there's no reason that companies shouldn't strike a better balance between dividends and buybacks and pay out 40% to 50% of their profits in dividends. Three industry groups -- telecom, utilities, and consumer staples -- already are in that range.   Jim Paulsen, chief investment strategist for Wells Capital Management, notes that in 1960, the S&P price-earnings ratio was comparable to the current P/E of 16, and interest rates were similar to those now. Dividend yields, however, were nearly double current levels. "The kicker is that in the next five years, the Dow rose almost 50%."   Corporations are wedded to big buybacks because executives believe that repurchases are the best way to lift share prices. And higher prices enrich corporate managers who have lush stock-option packages. Individuals, meanwhile, can benefit from buybacks to the extent that they defer paying capital gains.   With most major stock indexes at or near record levels, there's little pressure on companies to aggressively raise dividends when buybacks seem to be doing the job. It might take a bear market for executives to rediscover dividends; ample payouts tend to put a floor under stock prices. Then again, a sharp selloff might encourage even more aggressive buybacks, given the current corporate mindset.   "Retail buyers in the marketplace are crying for dividends, but the institutional investors on quarterly conference calls are calling for buybacks," says investor Ross Margolies.   Morgan Stanley's McVey acknowledges that buybacks are "running roughshod over dividends." In 2006, repurchases by companies in the S&P 500 hit a record $494 billion, while net repurchases, after equity issuance were $371 billlion. Dividends totaled $233 billion. Gross repurchases topped dividends by a more than 2-to-1 ratio.   "Companies used to lead with dividends and then add in buybacks," says S&P's Silverblatt. "Now, it's totally reversed. It's all about buybacks, with some dividends thrown in."   McVey estimates that almost half the S&P 500 bought back shares equal to 2% or more of their market value last year. Corporate managers defend buybacks by arguing that their stocks are cheap and that repurchases are the best use of corporate cash. It's harder to make that argument now, with so many stocks at or near record prices.   There are many examples of companies making large buybacks at high prices with money that should have gone to dividends. The newspaper industry and its leader, Gannett (GCI), are prime examples. So is Dell. Biotech leader Amgen spent over $9 billion in 2005 and 2006 repurchasing stock at an average price of $71. The recent share price: 54.   Amgen, Dell, Viacom and Oracle probably should pay dividends. All are mature businesses that generate lots of cash. At Berkshire Hathaway, investors haven't seen a dividend for 40 years. While Berkshire could easily pay an ample dividend, most of its shareholders are happy to see it retain all its earnings and let Warren Buffett deploy them in investments or acquisitions.   Within the financial sector, asset managers and Wall Street firms tend to have meager payouts. It's hard to understand why asset managers don't have bigger dividends, because their businesses require minimal capital. If profits at Goldman Sachs (GS) and its peers are near a cyclical peak, their big buybacks won't look so smart.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: 3 Mexican Directors Sign $100M Deal With Universal - Report
Story: LOS ANGELES (AP)--The three Mexican directors who shook up Hollywood last February with an astounding 16 Academy Award nominations have formed a moviemaking partnership with Universal Pictures worth a reported $100 million.   Guillermo del Toro, Alfonso Cuaron and Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu will call their production company Cha Cha Cha. They will produce five movies, some of them in Spanish, the Los Angeles Times reported Saturday.   "These filmmakers truly represent the importance of cultural diversity for the global audience," said David Linde, co-chairman of Universal Pictures, which is owned by General Electric Co. (GE).   Universal plans to distribute the trio's films abroad. A U.S.-Canadian distributor wasn't named. The total cost of the films could reach $100 million, according to the Times.   The three have marketed themselves as a trio since their stunning Oscar success.   Del Toro directed "Pan's Labyrinth," which won three Oscars and was nominated for six. Gonzalez Inarritu's "Babel" was nominated in seven categories, including best picture and best director, and won for best original score. Cuaron's "Children of Men" was nominated in three categories.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 14:01 ET (18:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) Tech Trader: Ignoring An Inconvenient Truth
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   Asian business media tapped Fredy Bush as the "entrepreneur of the year" last October for building her Xinhua Finance into a Chinese media and financial information powerhouse.   In just seven years, Xinhua has become a kind of McGraw-Hill of China -- with financial news services, stock indexes and ratings agencies. Listed in Tokyo, Bush's company's raised $300 million in March in a U.S. offering on behalf of its Xinhua Finance Media unit (ticker: XFML). Xinhua Finance has collected some influential U.S. assets this year, including the hard-hitting proxy advisory firm Glass Lewis that's staffed with veterans of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Wall Street Journal . . . or at least it was until last week.   That's when two of the most prestigious staffers at Glass Lewis resigned after apparently concluding that their new parent company, Xinhua Finance, would have flunked a Glass Lewis review of its corporate transparency. It turns out that Xinhua Finance Media's IPO prospectus failed to mention some awkward facts about the company's then-chief financial officer, Shelly Singhal.   The 39-year-old Singhal was simultaneously the company's CFO and an investment banker and stock broker who runs the Newport Beach, Calif., firm Bedrock Securities. And since April 2006, Singhal's firm has been under a cease- and-desist order from the National Association of Securities Dealers, as the regulators seek to suspend Bedrock for violating several SEC rules. I called Bedrock, but no one returned my message.   Singhal's name actually came up in Barron's May 7 issue ("New Controversy for iMergent"), where we reported that he was fighting a private civil racketeering suit in California courts for his investment activities. He got involved with Xinhua Finance as a major investor in 2003. He had previously been a major investor in a couple of companies called AremisSoft and ACLN -- which turned out to be outrageous frauds.   By coincidence, perhaps, our mention of Singhal on May 7 was followed Tuesday by a Xinhua Finance Media announcement that Singhal was moving from his role as chief financial officer of the U.S.-listed unit to become head of corporate development for the Cayman Island-based parent company's capital markets activities. Taking his place as CFO was David Wang, who had worked for Singhal's brokerage firm and investment bank.   Friday, Glass Lewis' head of research, Lynn E. Turner, resigned. Before joining Glass Lewis, Turner had been arguably the best accounting regulator to serve at the Securities and Exchange Commission. Wednesday, Glass Lewis' managing director and research editor, Jonathan Weil, resigned. He had come to the proxy advisory firm from the Wall Street Journal, where he was the first reporter to blow the whistle on Enron.   "I am uncomfortable with and deeply disturbed," Weil said in his resignation letter, "by the conduct, background and activities of our new parent company Xinhua Finance Ltd., its senior management, and its directors. To protect my reputation, I no longer can be associated with Glass Lewis or Xinhua Finance."   Shortly after I called Xinhua Finance Friday afternoon to ask about Singhal, the company put out a press release announcing that he was resigning from the boards of both Xinhua Finance and its Nasdaq-listed subsidiary, and also leaving his management positions. "It is a difficult decision to leave these two Companies that I have helped to grow," he said in the announcement, "but there are other priorities that will require my full attention, so it is clearly the right thing to do now."   A few moments later, I was on the phone with Xinhua Finance CEO Freddy Bush. She praised Singhal's skills at dealing with regulatory regimes in the U.S., Japan and China. "Shelly's got some very unique skills," she said.   I asked if she'd known about the NASD action against Singhal's brokerage firm when putting together a prospectus for Xinhua Finance Media that omitted that fact. After a long speech about how she had relied on the best advice of the company's underwriters and lawyers, she acknowledged that, "yes," she had known about the NASD problems of Singhal's brokerage firm. Her legal advisers told her, she said, that the prospectus didn't have to make that disclosure.   "Shelly continues to believe that these allegations are without merit," she continued. She also pointed out that Xinhua Finance has thousands of employees in more than a dozen countries. And even the proxy adviser Glass Lewis will survive the resignations of its marquee names, she asserted. "Glass Lewis has a very large group of incredibly talented people. Their product is world-class."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Andalucian Investors Mull EUR15B Buy Of Iberian Bank -Paper
Story: MADRID (Dow Jones)--A group of 27 Andalusian investors is looking to spend up to EUR15 billion on the acquisition of a midsized bank, and have identified at least four targets, three in Spain and one in Portugal, financial daily Expansion reported Saturday on its Web site.   The investor group, which includes some of the most wealthy individuals in the Southern Spanish region, is looking at Banco Popular SA (POP.MC), Banco Espanol de Credito SA (BTO.MC) - better known as Banesto - and Bankinter SA (BKT.MC), three of Spain's biggest domestically focused lenders.   Expansion said that the group, led by Antonio Martin de Cridado of Malaga, also wants to start talks with Portuguese lender Banco Espirito Santo S/A (BES.LB). The idea of the project is to create a strong bank with an Andalusian identity.   The group is negotiating potential financing and advisory with banks including UBS, Royal Bank of Scotland, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley, Expansion added.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.expansion.com     -By Christopher Bjork, Dow Jones Newswires; +34 91 395 8123; christopher.bjork@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 08:05 ET (12:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) Other Voices: Where Are Wall Street's Detectives?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Avner Mandelman   Last June, rumors spread that AMD, the second-largest microprocessor producer, might buy graphic-chip maker ATI. Opinions raged pro and con: why the sale made sense and why it didn't; why AMD couldn't prosper without ATI and why AMD would go bust if it bought it. Dozens of analysts and money managers spent megawatts of energy analyzing the potential combination in an almost Talmudic fashion. Their logical conclusion: The transaction didn't make sense and therefore wouldn't happen.   There was only one hitch: Practically no one bothered to verify physically what was taking place. For a hypothetical observer might have seen the top three AMD acquisition honchos arriving one late afternoon at ATI's Markham, Ontario, headquarters.   Such physical evidence trumped all "analysis" that happened only inside the skulls of those who never stood watch over ATI's HQ -- or paid students $15 an hour (say) to do so, with photographs of AMD's top people in one hand, cellphone in the other.   Please note: Because the execs were visible (in theory, yes) from across the road, the info thus gleaned was public -- valuable and closely held, yes, but public just the same.   It probably never has crossed the minds of 99% of analysts that information can be physical. Information for them is always equal to ink prints and screen-blips  -- second- and third-hand symbols to be manipulated with math and logic. Think of Aristotle, who proved with impeccable logic that a fly had eight legs because it could do with no less. It never occurred to the great philosopher to pick up a fly and count its legs. After all, once he had employed logic, why should he bother with physical reality?   Modern science is based on physical observation, not mere logic. And yet many investment analysts still behave like Aristotle. Most analysts and money managers move big money around based on second- and third-hand "info" only, and very few ever bestir themselves to count trucks, or follow executives around to see who they are meeting, or schmooze receiving clerks at their weekly bowling game to learn if they are busy at work or not, or bump "accidentally" into a company's main customers at the basketball court at the Y, or take the CEO's ancient secretary to a three-martini lunch, or peek into the company's warehouse from the Starbucks across the road to see whether the shelves are laden or bare.   And before you cry "insider information": Shipping clerks are not corporate officers, and so need not file an 8-K if they tell you are they are bored because of inaction; and your watching execs from across the road is perfectly legal, as is your schmoozing the customers' buyers in the Y, as are the 101 other sleuthing tricks performed every day by law-enforcement officers and intelligence operatives and newspaper reporters.   Nevertheless, the search for physical evidence is practically unknown among stock analysts. Imagine CIA officers basing their conclusions only on newspaper articles, without ever sending an Arab-speaking operative dressed in a djellabah to a barbershop in Fallujah, to mix with the populace and tell jokes in the local dialect and count the AK-47s leaning against the wall.   Of course, not everything that intelligence operatives and policemen can do is doable legally by stock sleuths. But much is, just like the (purely hypothetical) AMD/ATI case.   If investment is war -- you try to take the other fellow's money while he tries to take yours -- stock analysis is commercial intelligence, and like all intelligence operations, it has four key parts: agents in the field to provide exclusive information; case officers, who hand the agents their instructions; back-office analysts, also known as "boffins," who analyze the data gathered by agents and produce conclusions; and consumers of the results, either top brass or political decision makers, also known as "trigger pullers."   Military intelligence is valuable only if all these four functions are well done, and so it is with stock research. Unfortunately, the first two functions are often missing. Nearly all analysts see themselves as boffins -- stock scientists providing "opinions" based on logic (or math) to trigger-pullers, while only a vanishingly small number bother to sleuth for physical information -- indeed may not even recognize it staring them in the face.   Like what? Like photographs of the top two dozen people in AMD and their counterparts at ATI, for whom either you or your (hypothetical) student informants can watch. Like conversations revealing that a company's receiving clerks have been bowling a lot lately because shipments have been so slow, or that the president's secretary is taking a three-week vacation for the first time in two years even though the stock still sells at 32 times earnings.   Very few investors search for such physical info, and even fewer recognize its worth. Most stick to published numbers and written reports; they may occasionally listen to conference calls or talk with management. But the best source of data is often well down the corporate ladder, in the company and among its customers, or often simply available by watching the movement of people or products. Because so few bother to sleuth for physical info, those who do gain an edge that lets them take the others' money.   ---   AVNER MANDELMAN is president and chief investment officer at Giraffe Capital in Toronto and author of The Sleuth Investor (McGraw-Hill, 2007).   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) Protecting The World -- And Boosting Profits
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Sandra Ward   Each year for the three years it's been public, Genworth Financial has shown strong earnings growth and met or exceeded expectations for profitability. And that trend is expected to continue. Yet, for more than a year now, shares of the Richmond, Va.-based financial-services company have underperformed the other life insurers to which it is frequently compared.   Concerns about deterioration in its mortgage-insurance portfolio amid the housing downturn and fallout in the subprime-lending area have pressured the stock (ticker: GNW). Worries about losses in an existing block of long-term care insurance written before the late 1990s are also weighing on the shares.   That has created a nice opportunity for investors. Many find the worries overdone, and point to some compelling company fundamentals that should more than mitigate any risks.   In fact, Genworth is likely to benefit from some of the troubles now facing the U.S. mortgage industry as lenders offer more traditional mortgage products and fewer substitutes to mortgage insurance, which protects lenders from credit losses. As fewer mortgages are refinanced, Genworth's insurance policies should stay in force for longer.   The company also should also gain from a merger of two big mortgage-insurance rivals, winning new business as lenders concerned about concentrating too much business from the merged outfit look to other companies. The Tax Relief and Health Care Act of 2006, which makes mortgage-insurance tax-deductible for home owners, is also likely to give a boost to growth, as the product will be easier to sell.   Genworth expects revenue growth in its U.S. mortgage-insurance business of 15% to 20% in 2007, up from 9% growth in 2006 as it recaptures market share.   "The growth is underestimated," says Tim Kang of the $1.8 billion Olstein All-Cap Value Fund, which started purchasing the shares in November, when they traded between 32 and 33. He expects them to rise to 45 in the next 18 to 24 months -- about a 24% gain -- as Genworth allocates more money to higher-return businesses and improves its return on equity. It's also expected to keep buying back a good amount of its stock, funded by ample cash flow. It bought back $233 million shares in the first quarter and an additional $600 million from Merrill Lynch Friday.   Genworth's chipper and driven Chief Executive Michael Fraizer says he's confident the company can meet its ambitious earnings projections on the back of a trio of growth engines: its international mortgage-insurance and payment-protection business; fee-based retirement products; and life insurance. Combined with cost savings targeted at about $200 million in the next two years and the reallocation of capital to higher return areas, the company, he says, is on track to earn between $3.15 and $3.25 a share for 2007. That compares with $2.89 operating income per share in 2006. Also, management expects to increase revenue by 8%-to-10% a year on average for the next three years; boost earnings by 12% to 15% a year on average; and improve its return on equity to between 13% and 14% by 2010 or 2011.   "We're going to focus where we can win," says Fraizer. So Genworth has been exiting low-return areas like small-group insurance, travel insurance and structured settlements, a type of annuity awarded in personal-injury cases.     Expect more acquisitions in the fast-growing retirement/money-management side of the business, similar to its purchase of AssetMark Investment Services last year. "We would clearly like to accelerate the contribution of our fee-based retirement business to our mix, and we are seeing good organic growth there. But we will also try to complement that with targeted acquisitions," says Fraizer.   Changing hands recently near 37, Genworth shares trade at a sizeable discount to other life insurers, even assuming some discount is warranted because of its mortgage business. The mortgage-insurance portfolio, however, is considered to be of better quality and lower risk than that of many pure-play mortgage-insurance companies. And Genworth's international mortgage-insurance business, which contributes 27% of operating earnings and has a strong presence in the Canadian and Australian markets, likely deserves to trade at a premium to the U.S. mortgage business.   At 9.7 times projected '08 operating earnings, Genworth trades at a 12.9% discount to the Bear Stearns Cos. Life Insurers Index. Its multiple of 1.27 times book value represents a 27.9% discount to the same group. Those numbers, coupled with Genworth's growth projections, caught the attention of Bear Stearns life-insurance analyst Saul Martinez, who initiated coverage of Genworth in mid-April at 35.66 with an Outperform rating and a year-end price target of 42.   "It's got a lot of earnings leverage for a life insurance company selling at a single-digit multiple," says Schneider Capital Management's Arnie Schneider, which owned 3.3 million shares as of March 31. "There's very little downside, by nature of its valuation."   Bear Stearns estimates the company will report net income this year of $1.43 billion, or $3.22 a share, on revenue of $11.2 billion. For 2008, the brokerage firm projects net income of $1.56 billion, or $3.62 a share, on revenue of nearly $12 billion.     You can be forgiven if you haven't heard of Genworth, despite its nearly $16 billion market cap. Prior to its May 2004 IPO, it was tucked inside General Electric (GE) as a subsidiary of GE Financial Assurance Holdings. But you'll likely hear of it in the future -- or may have recently gotten a Genworth mailing about long-term care insurance, or seen one of its commercials on TV.   Pursuing a cradle-to-grave strategy of selling "financial security" -- everything from mortgage insurance to life insurance, annuities and long-term care insurance in 25 countries -- Genworth "caters to a broad swath of individuals in the U.S. and internationally," says Olstein's Kang. Operating in Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, Mexico and Japan, Genworth has amassed a vast client database filled with all sorts of personal information, giving it an edge in targeting its products.   The company is best known for its mortgage insurance and long-term care insurance -- the two areas that are weighing on it now. Problems in those areas contributed to a 3% drop in net income in the first quarter, to $324 million, or 71 cents a share, from $334 million in the year-ago period, or 70 cents a share. Wall Street had been expecting 77 cents a share.   Genworth, along with the rest of the industry, continues to suffer from poor pricing and poor underwriting standards on its long-term care policies written before the 1990s. The return on equity of that business is expected to fall into negative territory this year. "We are committed to dealing with that old block by improving the performance of it or reducing the capital associated with it and redeploying that elsewhere," says Fraizer. The good news is that the newer long-term care business is generating a 12% return on equity.   Notably, Genworth's U.S. mortgage-insurance business has relatively light exposure to the weakest area of mortgage lending: the subprime and low-documentation loan markets. Most Genworth borrowers have credit scores above 620, the cutoff for subprime, and are geographically well-dispersed.   Indeed, Genworth shares might be one of the best insurance policies of all.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) Follow-Up: Citi Holders Are In Good Company
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jack Willoughby   When hedge-fund manager Eddie Lampert moves, it's big news on Wall Street. Just how big was made clear last week when the billionaire investor disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that he had assembled an $800 million stake in Citigroup (ticker: C). Citi's shares rose 2.16, to 54.96, on the week, creating more than $10 billion in added market value. That's the kind of leverage even Warren Buffett would envy, and there could be more gains ahead.   The secretive Lampert is known for assuming an activist role in a handful of companies, and guiding their strategy. His leadership has produced handsome returns for shareholders of AutoZone (AZO) and Sears Holdings (SHLD), which has rallied more than tenfold since Lampert bought Kmart out of bankruptcy and merged it with Sears, Roebuck to form a new company.   Citigroup and its Chairman and CEO, Charles O. ("Chuck") Prince, have been battling rising shareholder criticism over the bank's tepid growth and sluggish stock price. Lampert's arrival, even with just 15.2 million shares, or less than 1%, is bound to stir other value investors.   "The presence of such a well-known activist will fire more searching... possibly leading to long-term change," says Joe Feshbach, a Palo Alto, Calif., hedge-fund manager. "If I were an investor, I would take great comfort that a good value investor like Lampert sees possibilities."   And Lampert is not the only one. As Barron's noted last summer in a cover story ("Fixing Citi," July 3, 2006), some analysts and investors are calling for a break-up of Citigroup, on the theory it would unlock at least $60 a share of value. Prince, however, has staked his tenure on internally generated growth.   So far, the results have been underwhelming. Earnings grew 7% last year, to $21.2 billion, or $4.25 a share, on revenue of $147.6 billion. Wall Street sees profits rising to $4.47 a share this year, and $5.04 in 2008.   While Lampert's intentions at Citi aren't clear, he managed to shield most of his purchases from public view by receiving "confidential treatment" from the SEC. The hedge-fund manager reportedly bought most of his stake last summer, and about a third of his position in the first quarter of this year. His confidentiality agreement expired in May. A Lampert spokesman declined to comment.   Lampert's purchases probably have reduced the amount of time Price has to turn Citi around. Speculation  has turned to the subject of a successor, with some market rumors focusing on NYSE Euronext (NXT) CEO John Thain.   For Citi holders, coming months could get a lot more interesting. And their shares could grow more valuable still.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) Follow-Up: Micron Looks Cheap
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   Disaster has overtaken the memory-chip market this year. Spot prices for DRAM memories have plunged 70% from December-quarter levels, in the worst meltdown since the tech bubble burst in 2000. That has clobbered memory makers like Micron Technology (ticker: MU), whose shares fell 5% to 11.50 Thursday when the Boise, Idaho-based company said it would offer $1.1 billion in convertible debt. Small wonder: They couldn't give the stock away.   Yet with a tangible book valueof about $8.60 a share (including the coming debt), the stock's downside risk is diminishing. It could be six to nine months before Micron sees profits again, but with spot prices of 512-megabit dynamic random-access memory chips, now around $1.75, approaching the marginal cost of production, price declines will slow. Such low prices, not only for DRAMs but the flash-memory chips that Micron also makes, could lift demand anew, and with it, Micron's shares.   Micron sat at 16 a share when we said last June its products would become less commodity-like ("Micron's New Muscle," June 5, 2006). But demand for memory chips failed to materialize after Microsoft's (MSFT) Vista software launch. We ate our words in January, with the stock at 14 ("The Memory Glut of 2007," Jan. 1, 2007); memory chips weren't commodity-like, but not in the way we'd expected. They are the only commodity whose prices have tanked.   Micron's May 2007 fiscal quarter is expected to turn out even worse than the February period, when the company lost $52 million, or 7 cents a share, on sales of $1.4 billion. Along with market gluts in DRAM and flash memories, Micron encountered a surfeit in the market for its image-sensor chips, as wireless-handset buyers favored cheaper models without cameras. Micron officials declined to talk with us last week.   Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial expect Micron to break even in fiscal 2007, ending August. For fiscal '08 they're predicting profits of about 40 cents a share, but a few more bad quarters might prompt Wall Street to revise that number downward.   Still and all, Micron's stock-market valuation of $8.7 billion represents about 1.5 times trailing-12-month sales -- toward the lower end of the stock's post-bubble price-to-sales range. It may be time to eat our words again.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited by Anita Peltonen   Handle With Care   A Guide to the Best-Managed Stock Funds   by Equity Fund Outlook     P.O. Box 76, Boston, Mass. 02117     June 1: Don't assume that the market will unravel just because of the season. But you might lean to the cautious side of your risk range in any trading decisions. Ease up on the specialty items, such as emerging markets and real estate; favor efficient, flexible funds within your risk ceiling. If choices are limited, overweight those with which you are comfortable.   -- Thurman Smith   Permit Picture   Mission Residential   by Mission Residential Research     103 East 5th St., Austin, Texas 78701     May 16: Housing starts unexpectedly rose in April . . . but the April permits data may indicate our [bearish] sentiment was correct: Total permits declined by 8.9%, to the lowest permit figure posted since June 1997. Single-family permits fell by 6%, to their lowest level since August 1997; multifamily permits plunged by 16.4%, marking the lowest level since July '01.   Thus, the permit data point to a significant decline in starts in the coming months, and this signal is strengthened by yesterday's report from the National Association of Home Builders showing that builder sentiment fell to a 16-year low in May.   -- Richard Moody     Big Blue Goes Green   New and Notable by Green Signals   by Signal Hill Capital Group     1 Embarcadero Ctr., San Francisco, Calif. 94111     May 16: IBM announced plans to invest $1 billion a year to double the energy efficiency of its data centers and those of its corporate customers. . . . The tech giant plans to double the computing capacity of its data centers by 2010 without increasing power consumption by using . . . systems that cool only as need[ed], software to automatically switch computers to standby mode, and thermal engineering to optimize air flow. IBM plans to offer these technologies to its customers as well, for whom it designs and builds data centers.   -- Michael Carboy, Elain Kwei   Paper Chase   The Option Queen     Box 1952 c/o New York Board of Trade   1 North End Ave., New York, N.Y. 10282     May 16: Our concern with inflation is now addressed to the food and raw-materials categories. . . . We're now able to see the beginnings of some cracks in the foundation of the market. The selloffs, rare as they are, seem to be getting deeper. Box 573, Kahului, Hawaii 96733     May 15: Did the domestic economy experience a rebound or merely an inventory adjustment? It's my estimation that the latter was the case. If that's the situation, then the bond market can enjoy another rally. But in all likelihood, it will be a brief one.   The question marks regarding the business landscape continue to be a positive element for the [bond] market. Headline: Barron's(5/21) Barron's Mailbag: Spelling Tailspin
Story: (From BARRON'S)   To the Editor:     The May 7 article about Delta Air Lines ("Delta Roars Back to Life") should be an embarrassment to your editorial staff and author Thomas G. Donlan. The report is replete with mistakes. Delta airlines is listed as having ticker symbol DEAL. Delta is actually DAL. The Delta CEO is "Grinstein" not "Greenstone." There were many other mistakes. I can't believe you were in such a rush to publish that simple proofreading could not be done!   Kent Fields   Leesburg, Va.     Thomas G. Donlan replies: Indeed, we are embarrassed, and we ran a correction on this last week. As a final step in the proofreading, the article was subjected to an automated spell-check program. The operator apparently pressed "Accept All Changes" instead of "Reject All Changes." We apologize, and we've made a corrected version of the story available free on Barron's Online.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:01 ET (04:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Cerberus Secures $62B Package To Refinance Chrysler Debt
Story: NEW YORK (AP)--Cerberus Capital Management on Friday said seven major North American banks and investment banks have agreed to raise the $62 billion needed to refinance the debt and recapitalize Chrysler Group.   The New York-based private equity firm announced on Monday it would acquire the U.S. automaker from Germany's Daimler-Chrysler AG (DCX) for $7.4 billion. But Cerberus revealed little else about how it would finance the takeover.   The mix of financing will include securities backed by the Chrysler's automobile assets, high-yield corporate debt, and bank loans, said Cerberus spokesman Peter Duda. Leading the financing is JPMorgan Chase & Co., Goldman Sachs Group Inc., Citigroup Inc., Morgan Stanley, Bear Stearns Cos., Toronto-Dominion Bank, and the Royal Bank of Canada.   Some $50 billion of proceeds will be used to refinance debt at Chrysler's financing unit. The amount will be the largest refinanced by a private equity firm, according to financial data tracker Dealogic.   DaimlerChrysler Chief Financial Officer Bodo Uebber said during a conference call on Monday that the new Chrysler would likely carry a "BB" junk rating after it splits from DaimlerChrysler, which has a "BBB" investment-grade rating. The lower rating would equate to higher borrowing costs.   As part of the $62 billion financing, the banks have agreed to secure $12 billion in loans that Cerberus can draw from to help in the restructuring. It was not known how the banks would split that amount.   As part of the $7.4 billion takeover price for the deal, Cerberus agreed to contribute $5 billion directly to the car maker and $1.05 billion would be pumped into its financing arm. Daimler-Chrysler will receive roughly $1.35 billion of the amount.   But other expenses to be absorbed by Daimler mean the German company's net cost of getting rid of the money-losing U.S. unit will actually rise to as much as $1.5 billion. That includes a $400 million loan, among other payments, as part of the transaction.   Daimler also is on the hook to pay $1 billion into Chrysler's pension fund should the fund be terminated within five years of the sale. Cerberus said it would pay $200 million into the pension fund, which would come out of the deal price, the private equity firm said.   The acquisition unwinds the 1998 takeover of the parent company of the Chrysler, Jeep and Dodge brands by Daimler-Benz through a stock exchange that Thomson Financial valued at $33 billion, excluding assumed debt.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 02:21 ET (06:21 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Russian Min: No Kamaz Privatization This Year -Tass
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--There will be no privatization of Kamaz (KMAZ.RS) in 2007, Russian Economic Development Minister Gherman Gref said at an international investment forum in Kazan, the capital city of the Republic of Tatarstan, Itar-Tass reported Saturday.   "We do not plan to privatize KamAZ this year. We've agreed with the government of the Republic of Tatarstan that we will let the company come onto the exchange in the third quarter of 2008 and float an additional issue of shares," the minister said at the forum "Russian Regions - Growth Strategy," according to Tass. He reiterated that money from the share floating would not come to the federal budget, but would be used for development of the company.   As a result of the floating of shares, Russia's stake in the company will decrease, Tass said, but the capitalization will grow. Tass noted that 34.01% of the shares in the KamAZ company belong to the Russian Federation.   The heavy truck maker is included in the privatization plan for 2007 with the note "until the government's special decision."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 09:39 ET (13:39 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) Asian Trader: Australia's First $100 Stock?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Susan Murdoch   Merck has been getting plenty of market accolades for its cervical-cancer vaccine, Gardasil. But CSL, the Australian outfit that discovered the breakthrough product, is also poised to reap big rewards.   The "blue-sky" potential from Gardasil royalties for the licensing of development and distribution to Merck is just one factor that has analysts betting that CSL (ticker: CSL.Australia) could be the first Australian company to pop through the 100-Australian dollars-a-share mark (US$82.38).   CSL's main money spinners are actually blood-plasma products, accounting for around 87% of the company's roughly A$2.9 billion in annual revenue. The Melbourne-based biopharmaceutical firm is the world's second-largest maker of plasma-derived items behind the U.S.' Baxter International (BAX) and is benefiting from tight supply, which has boosted plasma product prices -- and sent CSL's earnings soaring.   In February, CSL unveiled its second profit upgrade in less than two months, raising its fiscal year (June) 2007 profit guidance by as much as 18%, to between A$500 million and A$520 million. The stock has since climbed nearly 20% to A$92.80; eight of the 11 analysts covering the company maintain Buy or Overweight recommendations, according to Thomson Financial. Bullish UBS, for instance, has a price target of A$100.   "CSL has always surprised analysts on the upside, and it has the potential to be able to do that again," says Intersuisse analyst Darren Grubb, citing margin growth and possible new uses for CSL's main plasma product, intravenous immunoglobulin, or IVIG.   Demand for IVIG -- used to help the body fight infection -- is estimated to be growing about 10%-to-15% annually, mainly to treat conditions not specifically approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. For instance, one potential use is as a treatment for Alzheimer's disease. That application is due to enter Phase II clinical trials in the U.S. and Europe next year.   "Going forward, more trials into IVIG and Alzheimer's disease are required, but should these trials be positive, early-adopter physicians and doctors are likely to drive increased use of IVIG," ABN AMRO analyst David Stanton said in a May 9 report.   By the end of this year, CSL also expects U.S. regulatory approval for a liquid form of IVIG, which analysts say should bring 30%-plus profit margins.   The outlook for CSL wasn't always so bullish. In 2003, its plasma business threatened to unravel when prices crashed due to oversupply; CSL shares plummeted from A$52 to a low of A$11.57. The glut spurred Aventis, now Sanofi-Aventis (SNY), to seek a buyer for its plasma unit. CSL Chief Executive Brian McNamee stepped in, paying almost A$1 billion to acquire the business -- twice the size of his own plasma division -- and the bet paid off.   The deal helped improve the dynamics for the whole industry, as U.S. collection centers were consolidated. With several key barriers to entering the market, including a three-to-four-year lead time in setting up new centers, UBS analyst Andrew Goodsall estimates demand for plasma product should be "tight" until at least 2010.   One possible risk to earnings growth is a strong Australian dollar -- hovering near a 17-year high against the U.S. currency -- creating a headwind for Gardasil's U.S. royalties. (CSL has retained Australian sales rights.)   Controversy has also surrounded Gardasil, which targets the human papillomavirus thought to cause most cervical cancers. The drug has sparked debate about whether preteen girls should be vaccinated, and, earlier this month, an editorial published in the New England Journal of Medicine raised questions about its overall effectiveness.   Still, global demand for Gardasil is rising fast. Merck last month reported first-quarter sales for the vaccine of US$365 million, exceeding market estimates. Analysts expect annual sales will peak around US$2.9 billion in 2011.   CSL forecasts A$40 million to A$50 million in maiden Gardasil royalties this year, but this guidance appears conservative. UBS and Goldman Sachs JBWere both say these payouts could exceed A$70 million in fiscal 2007 as U.S. sales progress and European sales begin to kick in.   "The earnings risk for CSL continues to be skewed to the upside, even in the face of the appreciating Australian dollar," GSJBW analyst Hamish Tadgell wrote in a report last week.   CSL's research and development pipeline can't be ignored either. Last year, it added to its suite with the acquisition of small Australian biotech Zenyth, which is researching arthritis and cancer treatments. CSL is also seeking approval from the U.S. FDA to sell its seasonal influenza vaccine.   Solid cash flows from Gardasil sales and the plasma business are expected to leave CSL debt-free by 2009, opening up the possibility of a share buyback.   Such strong cash flows are also a characteristic that attracts private-equity firms by enabling them to quickly pay down debt in leveraged deals. ABN AMRO's Stanton has included a takeover premium in his target price on the stock. Peter Quinton, director of research at brokerage Bell Potter, agrees CSL falls within the radar of deal-hungry buyout groups.   "Absolutely, it's a global leader, prices are going up, it's got a very strong balance sheet and a royalty on what looks like another global blockbuster drug -- Gardasil," Quinton says. "CSL's going to hit A$100."   ---   Susan Murdoch is a reporter for Dow Jones Newswires in Melbourne.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Genesis Healthcare Announces Amended Merger Agreement with Formation Capital And JER Partners
Story: Shareholders to Receive Increased Price of $69.35 per Share in   Cash, Increasing at 9% per annum Beginning July 31, and at 10% per                      annum Beginning September 1      Board of Directors Recommends Shareholders Vote In Favor of                       Formation/JER Transaction  KENNETT SQUARE, Pa.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--May 19, 2007--   Genesis HealthCare Corporation ("GHC" or "Genesis") (NASDAQ: GHCI) today announced that it has amended its merger agreement with a venture between affiliates of Formation Capital, LLC ("Formation") and JER Partners ("JER") to increase the consideration payable to Genesis shareholders to $69.35 per share in cash. Under the amended agreement, if the transaction is not completed prior to July 31, 2007, the purchase price will increase by approximately 9% per annum, or $0.01710 per day, from July 31, 2007 through August 31, 2007, and by approximately 10% per annum, or $0.01900 per day, from September 1, 2007 until the transaction closes.     The Board of Directors of Genesis, acting on the unanimous recommendation of a Special Committee consisting solely of independent, non-management directors, has approved the amended merger agreement and recommends that shareholders vote in favor of the Formation/JER transaction.     In making their recommendation to approve the amended merger agreement, the Special Committee and the Board of Directors determined that the revised offer from Formation/JER is superior to the previously announced proposal from Fillmore Capital Partners, LLC ("Fillmore"). Under that proposal, Fillmore offered to acquire all outstanding common shares of Genesis for $69.25, increasing by 8% per annum, or $0.01518 per day, from September 1, 2007 until the transaction closes.     The increased price of the Formation/JER transaction values Genesis at approximately $1.9 billion, including the assumption of approximately $475 million in debt, and represents a premium of approximately 44.3 % over the average closing price for GHC common stock over the 30 days prior to announcement of the original transaction on January 16, 2007. Under the amended transaction announced today, the termination fee to be paid by Genesis to Formation and JER in the event that Genesis enters into a superior transaction with a third party would be $40 million.     The adjourned annual meeting of shareholders, at which the vote on the Formation/JER transaction will take place, is scheduled for May 30, 2007 at 10:00 a.m. The meeting will be held at Genesis headquarters in Kennett Square, Pennsylvania. Only shareholders of record as of March 5, 2007 are entitled to vote at the annual meeting.       About Genesis HealthCare Corporation     Genesis HealthCare Corporation (NASDAQ: GHCI) is one of the nation's largest long-term care providers with over 200 skilled nursing centers and assisted living residences in 13 eastern states. Genesis also supplies contract rehabilitation therapy to over 600 healthcare providers in 20 states and the District of Columbia.       About Formation and JER     Formation Capital is a private equity firm in the senior housing and long-term care industry. Over the past five years Formation Capital has completed over $1.5 billion of acquisitions in the sector and provides asset management services to over 250 facilities nationwide. For more information on Formation Capital, please visit www.formationcapital.com.     JER Partners is the private equity investment arm of J.E. Robert Companies, a real estate investment management company with more than 25 years of experience in sourcing, underwriting and managing a broad spectrum of real estate equity investments and debt products in North America and Europe. JER has completed over $1.1 billion of acquisitions in the senior housing sector. JER's primary investments are in office, hospitality, retail, multi-family, healthcare-related real estate and industrial properties. Other areas of investment include commercial mortgage-backed securities ("CMBS") and mezzanine financing. For more information on JER, please visit www.jer.com.       Forward-Looking Statements     A number of the matters discussed in this document that are not historical or current facts deal with potential future circumstances and developments, in particular, information regarding the expected timetable for completing the transaction, successful integration of the business, benefits of the transaction and any other statements contained in this news release that are not purely historical fact are forward-looking statements. The discussion of such matters is qualified by the inherent risks and uncertainties surrounding future expectations generally, and also may materially differ from actual future experience involving any one or more of such matters. Such forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected. Such risks and uncertainties include, but are not limited to, the approval of the proposed merger by regulatory agencies, approval of the merger by the shareholders of GHC, satisfaction of various other conditions to the closing of the merger contemplated by the merger agreement and the risks that have been described from time to time in GHC's reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC"), including its definitive proxy statement in connection with the 2007 annual meeting of shareholders and its annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended September 30, 2006. This document speaks only as of its date, and each of GHC, JER and Formation disclaims any duty to update the information herein.       Additional Information and Where to Find It:     On March 7, 2007, GHC filed with the SEC, and thereafter furnished to shareholders, a definitive proxy statement in connection with its 2007 annual meeting of shareholders. Since March 7, GHC has filed additional proxy soliciting materials, including a proxy supplement that was filed with the SEC on April 23, 2007 and a proxy supplement that was filed with the SEC on May 4, 2007, and GHC expects to furnish shareholders with additional proxy material, including a proxy supplement, relating to the amendment to the merger agreement announced today. Investors and security holders are urged to read the proxy statement, its supplements and other documents filed or to be filed by GHC because they contain (or will contain when available) important information about the proposed merger. Investors and security holders may obtain a free copy of the proxy statement, its supplements and other documents filed by GHC (when available) at the SEC website at http://www.sec.gov. The proxy statement, its supplements and other documents also may be obtained for free from GHC by directing such request to Genesis HealthCare Corporation, Investor Relations, 101 East State Street, Kennett Square, PA 19348; telephone: 610-925-2000.       Participants in the Solicitation     GHC and its directors, executive officers and other members of its management and employees may be deemed participants in the solicitation of proxies from its stockholders in connection with the proposed merger and GHC's scheduled 2007 annual meeting. Information regarding the persons who may, under the rules of the SEC, be considered participants in the solicitation of proxies from GHC shareholders is set forth in GHC's proxy statement filed on March 7, 2007 and in its proxy statements and Annual Reports on Form 10-K previously filed with the SEC.        CONTACT: GHC Investors:               Jim McKeon, CFO, 610-444-8425               Lori Mayer, Director Investor Relations, 610-925-2000               Or               GHC Media:               Jim Barron/Renee Soto, 212-687-8080        SOURCE: Genesis HealthCare Corporation  Copyright Business Wire 2007     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 13:14 ET (17:14 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(5/21) If You Can Find A Better Stock, Buy It
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jay Palmer   DaimlerChrysler is dead; long live Daimler. That sentiment, albeit a bit premature, was in evidence on Wall Street last week, after the rocky marriage of what once were known as Daimler-Benz and Chrysler Corp. officially headed toward a divorce.   DaimlerChrysler stock (ticker: DCX) closed Friday at 86.72; a year earlier, it had stood below 52. Some savvy investors figure that the new Daimler, which probably will begin trading under that name sometime soon, is still abargain. "Doing a sum-of-the-parts valuation, Mercedes is in Daimler for free," argues Adam Jonas, an analyst with Morgan Stanley in London, who values that car unit alone at between $30 and $40 a share. Indeed, bulls on the stock think it could hit 100 or more within a year.   Control of Chrysler is being bought by New York's Cerberus Capital Management, a private-equity firm run by former U.S. Treasury Secretary John Snow.   Cerberus is paying $7.4 billion for an 80.1% stake in Chrysler, with Daimler retaining the remainder (and the two vehicle makers continuing key joint programs for procurement, powertrain development, logistics and financial services). However, of that, $5 billion will go to Chrysler's vehicle business and $1.05 billion into Chrysler's financial-services unit. Daimler will get the balance -- but only theoretically, since it will absorb an estimated $1.6 billion worth of Chrysler's negative cash flow between now and the deal's closing, pay about $878 million to clear some Chrysler liabilities and make Chrysler a long-term loan of $400 million.   In essence, Daimler is paying more than $650 million to Cerberus to take Chrysler off its hands.     From Daimler's viewpoint, the key point is that Cerberus is assuming responsibility for the American car maker's nearly $18 billion in unfunded medical benefits for workers and retirees, the legacy of years of generous settlements with the United Auto Workers. The union, which will start negotiating for a new contract this summer, insists that Cerberus has promised no layoffs or benefit cuts before 2008 beyond those already planned. After that, however, Cerberus, along with General Motors (GM) and Ford (F) probably will demand hefty concessions.   That adds lots of uncertainty about the ultimate outcome of Cerberus' deal. On the other hand, Daimler's future looks far more certain -- and quite bright. In fact, Daimler looks very much like the company it was in the 1980s, before CEO Edzard Reuter and his successor, Jurgen Schrempp, remolded it through acquisitions, investments and alliances -- most ill-fated.   With its stake in the EADS aerospace consortium sold earlier this year, Daimler is again mainly a maker of Mercedes-Benz luxury cars and the world's biggest producer of trucks, sold mainly under the Mercedes and (in the U.S.) Freightliner brands. Both operations look healthy, as does Daimler's much smaller vehicle-financing operation.   In the first quarter, Mercedes returned to profitability, earning 792 million euros ($1.07 billion) before interest and taxes, compared with a loss of 735 million euros a year earlier. The truck group earned 528 million euros ($715.4 million) versus 422 million euros. Daimler's financial-services arm earned a pretax profit of 419 million euros ($567.7 million), down from 455 million euros.     There are still problems, most notably weak demand in Germany, Daimler's biggest market, following both a sharp increase in the country's value-added tax and the earlier problems with brand quality. Then there's the Smart Car, a small vehicle that's never made a profit and whose sales have spiralled downward in Europe, but which the company is about to introduce in the U.S.   Mercedes also has some catching up to do, especially with BMW, which thanks to a raft of hot new models now posts bigger global sales. Mercedes' biggest immediate challenge comes with this year's launch of its C Class model, its top seller globally. That will be followed by a new B-class, CLK coupe and E-class in 2009, complementing the new S Class launched last year.   However, many new models will share many more components than previous generations, potentially boosting profitability.     The truck operation has been hurt by the downturn in the U.S. market -- many truckers purchased vehicles in 2006, to beat price increases imposed by manufacturers to meet costly engine-emission standards that took effect this year. Nonetheless, it remains in the black.   Still, there's pressure on Daimler to restructure its U.S. truck operations, fix or close its ailing Japanese truck unit and slash costs in Europe to catch up with what rival Volvo, the Swedish truck maker, already has achieved.   Some analysts even speculate that the truck and auto operations could be split through a spinoff. However, because there are lots of synergies between the two, that's unlikely any time soon.   Daimler CEO Dieter Zetsche has extensive knowledge of trucks, having once headed Freightliner. In any case, "there is a lot that Daimler can achieve to improve returns," says Morgan Stanley's Jonas.   Notes Max Warburton, a UBS analyst in London: "Ex-Chrysler, Daimler is already an 8% margin business. Management is committed to unlocking value and the 'new Daimler' is set to be a high-margin, high-cash-flow business." The stock, Jonas and Warburton argue, is worth over $100.   One potential danger is that, if things go badly for Chrysler, angry workers could in the future still sue to force Daimler to stand by existing health benefits, regardless of what Cerberus and Daimler have hammered out. "Zetsche insists this can't happen, but Americans are a litigious lot," notes Warburton. Presumably, any such litigation would revolve around "fraudulent conveyance," in which someone tries to get out of a lawful obligation by transferring ownership to someone else. The fact that Daimler's essentially giving away Chrysler could be an issue.   But if Cerberus makes Chrysler profitable and healthy again, the issue won't arise.     Cerberus' auto division, run by former Ford executive David Thursfield, includes Peguform, a German manufacturer of plastic parts for vehicle interiors, a 51% holding in GMAC, General Motors' financing arm, auto suppliers CTA Acoustics, GDX Automotive and Alamo and National rental-car companies.   But it faces its biggest challenge in Chrysler, which lost $2.01 billion in the first quarter and plans to close a plant and lay off 13,000 people, more than 15% of its workforce. Tom LaSorda, Chrysler's boss and the architect of these cutbacks, will stay on. Cerberus stressed its support for his plans, and apparently has set no specific timetable for a turnaround.   "We can take the long view with Chrysler," declared John Snow last week. "We're not putting a clock on it." The little-known truth is that, but for the health-care burden (and its unfortunate focus on gas-guzzling and now slow-selling SUVs), Chrysler is pretty efficient, boasting some of the global industry's more productive plants and a low ratio of workers to vehicles built.   One option to handle the health-care problem could be a deal like that Goodyear has swung. Earlier this year, it terminated its health-care burden with the United Steel Workers by paying 77 cents for each dollar of obligations into a union-controlled trust fund.   Says John Rabb, an auto consultant in London: "For Cerberus, the challenge is to build on this, to push through new cost savings and somehow address the medical problem, all without alienating the UAW. Give Chrysler five years of freedom from having to report quarterly progress, and I think you could see a very different and much stronger company emerge."   That's what Cerberus -- and Daimler --  are hoping to see.   The crowning irony: If Chrysler becomes profitable again, Daimler could benefit more from its remaining 19.9% stake than it did during the nine years it owned 100% of the company.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) European Trader: Buyback Won't Bail Out ING
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Arindam Nag   ING has offered shareholders some fresh inducements to keep the faith. The Dutch financial-services group is returning 5 billion euros to investors by buying back shares, and it's also merging its domestic retail businesses -- Postbank and ING Bank -- to create efficiencies and expanding the reach of its online savings unit, ING Direct, to Japan.   The timing of these initiatives is no accident. They coincide with lackluster first-quarter results. So ING, whose New York-listed American depositary shares (ticker: ING) have been trading in the mid-40s, needs some bold moves to engineer a higher rating for its stock.   The 5 billion euro share buyback is equivalent to 7% of ING's stock-market capitalization. Some of its peers are returning a lower proportion of their market value or, like Allianz (AZ), are still undecided about what to do with their excess capital.   The buyback implies that if ING shares stay at their current level -- 26% below their 2000 peak -- the company will keep purchasing them, rather than get involved in any possibly value-destroying acquisitions.   While the buyback looks like a quick -- albeit generous -- fix, investors are bound to pay more attention to the Postbank-ING Bank merger. It's expected to generate pretax savings of 440 million euros. Taxed at 25% and capitalized, that's equivalent to roughly 2.4 billion euros, or an extra 1.1 euros per share.   And if ING can crack the notoriously difficult Japanese market with its online banking operation, it will have found some welcome geographic diversification with reasonable long-term growth prospects.   But the underlying frailty of some its activities are sure to bug investors. In the first quarter, costs at ING's banking business were high, while interest income was low. Performance across its life-insurance operations was weak, particularly in the U.S., where it had only a 9.5% internal rate of return. That figure, the lowest in three years, is down from 11.6% in 2006, despite the integration of some acquisitions, which should have boosted results.   There's hope that the U.S. business may improve later this year, once ING has changed the status of its local operation to that of an onshore insurer, freeing up regulatory capital. This should push the internal rate of return above its hurdle rate of 10.5%, though the business' fundamental growth driver -- product sales -- needs to improve, too.   Indeed, ING is rushing to find ways to keep shareholders happy, precisely because its insurance business has been a drag on its shares, especially recently. Over the past five years, ING stock generally has performed in line with the Dow Jones Stoxx Global 1800/Financial Services index. But it trailed that benchmark by 7% in the past two years and 13% in the past year.   ING stock trades at a price-earnings multiple of 10. Bank of America (BAC) trades at 11, while JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and even beleaguered Citigroup (C) trade at 13. Unless the Dutch company's performance improves, its shares are likely to remain laggards.   ---                         DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES    Region/  Country     DJ Global          DJ Global           DJ Global     Point      Indexes,           Indexes,            Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg.
