Headline: Saudi Aramco Extends Ras Tanura Refinery Maintenance To Jun 8
Story: RIYADH (Zawya Dow Jones)--Saudi Arabian Oil Co., the world's largest oil company by production, said Saturday it will extend the regular maintenance at its Ras Tanura refinery on the Persian Gulf coast by almost three weeks.   "Due to technical reasons, Saudi Aramco decided to extend the period of regular maintenance in Ras Tanura refinery until June 8," the company said in a statement to state-run news agency SPA.   Aramco didn't say when maintenance work at the refinery had started and what the facility's current operational status is.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 05:55 ET (09:55 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(5/21) The Dividend Dearth: Still Too -2-
Story: Many corporations, particularly those in the tech sector, view paying a dividend as an admission that their growth prospects are slowing. However, the best growth companies of the past few decades, General Electric (GE), PepsiCo, Procter & Gamble and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), have been able to expand their businesses, boost profits and pay sizable dividends.   One reason that corporations prefer buybacks is that they're much easier to curtail or eliminate if business worsens. Investors expect dividends to be maintained, short of financial catastrophe, and companies are loath to cut them. "A dividend is like marriage, while a buyback is living together," says investor Margolies. General Motors (GM), for instance, has maintained a $1 annual payout despite its financial woes, while Ford (F) reluctantly eliminated its dividend last year.   Economically sensitive companies that don't want to commit to a sharply higher regular quarterly dividend can pay a modest quarterly, supplemented by an annual dividend pegged to profits. Paccar (PCAR), the truck maker, has long pursued this approach while Diamond Offshore Drilling (DO), a provider of offshore rigs to the energy industry, began doing so in 2006. Diamond, whose shares trade at 92, has a quarterly payout of 12.5 cents a share. It supplemented that with a $4 special dividend in early 2007, based on 2006 earnings of $5 a share. Diamond could pay out $30 a share in dividends in the coming years if current Street profit projections are accurate and if it continues its high payout strategy.   "I call it libertarian capitalism," says Jim Tisch, the company's CEO. "The shareholder has the ability to decide. If the shareholder is in favor of a share repurchase, he can use the dividend to purchase shares -- in which case he would be in essentially the same position as if the company bought in shares." If a shareholder wants cash, he or she can just bank the dividend. Tisch also is CEO of Loews, the New York conglomerate controlled by the Tisch family. Loews owns 50% of Diamond Offshore.   University of Pennsylvania professor Jeremy Siegel notes that special annual dividends were common among cyclical companies in 1950s and 1960s: "General Motors used to do it all the time. It was like a Christmas present to shareholders."   Despite the benefits of dividends, the stock-repurchase habit is tough to break. But in the long run, companies that kick it may do more for their shareholders than any buyback can accomplish.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) Follow-Up: Northrop Grumman: Still Flying High
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Neil A. Martin   Shares of defense contractor Northrop Grumman (ticker: NOC) have rallied about 18%, to 76.75, since we highlighted the company's prospects a year ago ("Playing Defense to Win," June 5, 2006). There could be more gains in store if Northrop wins a contract to build an aerial-refueling tanker for the U.S. Air Force, on which it is bidding with Airbus Industries, the French unit of European Aeronautic, Defence & Space, or EADS (EAD.France).   Talk among defense-industry analysts is that the Bush administration might want to reach out to France, which just elected a pro-American president, by splitting the contract, valued at $40 billion over 15 years, between Boeing (BA) and the Northrop Grumman-Airbus team. A decision is expected in October.   Byron Callan, an analyst at Prudential Equity Group, wagers a Northrop win could add "a couple of bucks" to the company's share price. "Northrop's prospects may have improved based on the recent French election results," Callan says. "Splitting the contract would avoid a pretty contentious debate over who received the contract, and why."   With revenue exceeding $30 billion, Northrop is benefiting from record military spending, supplemental budgets for the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan and the outsourcing of government services. It's the world's biggest shipbuilder and a leading advanced-aircraft developer.   Analysts have been critical of Northrop's weak margins and competitive disadvantages, as most big defense firms have far more exposure to the army. Twenty of 23 Wall Street watchers rate the stock a Hold. To contrarians, that sort of imbalance means Buy.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) Making The Most Of A "Stockpicker's Market"
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Sandra Ward   Interview With Cliff Hoover   Co-chief investment officer, Dreman Value Management     Meet David Dreman's hand-picked successor to run $21.5 billion Dreman Value Management, based in Jersey City, N.J. And who better than Cliff Hoover to take over such a storied operation? Cut from the same value cloth as Dreman, a pioneer in contrarian investment strategies and behavioral finance, Hoover brings the same devotion to low P/Es and to dividends as a means of producingsuperior performance. Barron's readers will recall Hoover's outstanding stockpicking at Allianz's NFJ Investments, where he co-managed portfolios with Ben Fisher. Hoover, who is managing the DWS-Dreman High Return fund, will take complete charge when the 71-year-old Dreman decides to call it quits, though no date is set. He tells us there's no better time to be investing in high-quality stocks trading below their intrinsic value.     Barron's: We're setting new records in the Dow almost daily and the S&P 500 crossed 1500. All's right with the world?   Hoover: I don't think so. We gauge the market's value by the Value Line Composite, and by that measure the average stock is still fairly expensive. Two years ago, it was 19 times earnings, last year it was 19 times and, lo and behold, this year it is 19.4 times earnings.     Q: Still, you've been able to post good numbers in that environment.   A: It has been a pretty good stockpicker's market, and it is going to get better. It's late in the value-stock cycle. We've had relative value styles that have worked and a lot of quant-value styles that have worked. Value, in general, will hold up pretty well for the next couple of years given where we are with valuations and given the economy is clearly slowing down. There is going to be enough volatility that a good old-fashioned 12 1/2-P/E portfolio with close to a 3% dividend yield is probably not going to be a bad place to be over the next 12 to 18 months. We saw a little bit of turbulence in February, but that was just a slight warning signal.     Q: You expect a bigger correction?   A: Sure. The market is going to wake up at some point. It really is not discounting any risk.     Q: Isn't that easy to do when you have a market with so much liquidity?   A: It is easy to do. You know what the economist Hyman Minsky said: "Long periods of stability breed future instability." Everything is rocking along pretty well, but as you saw in February, it doesn't take much of a spark to create a fire.     Q: What would you expect to trigger a more severe correction?   A: It could be some type of financial-institution crisis. The fed-funds rate is a little over 3% on a real basis. Most of our financial crises have occurred when there's been a fairly high real fed-funds rate; most of them have come when the fed-funds' real rate is greater than 3%.     Q: Is the housing downturn manageable or is it likely to lead to more problems?   A: It is probably more problematic. The big question is how much does it spill over to consumer sentiment and eventually consumer spending? That multiplier effect is really the unknown. But subprime lending will be on the downtrend for many years.     Q: Isn't the market giving mixed signals? Jobs have held up well, for instance.   A: Jobs have held up, but we are starting to see some weakness. The Fed is watching all this closely, and when push comes to shove, they are going to start cutting rates, maybe late this summer if things continue to deteriorate, which should stabilize the market.     Q: Some think the next move is up.   A: The Fed is between a rock and a hard place. They are talking hawkish with the dollar under pressure, but let's face it, there is enough debt in the system that it could become critical to buoy the consumer. Fed Chairman Bernanke's background is on deflationary periods in history. His thesis was on deflation. He will not allow a whiff of that to begin, and so if the economy continues to weaken, he would clearly hedge on the side of taking rates down a bit. We have a very cautious outlook. There are record profit margins, record earnings, and the E in P/E is probably a bit vulnerable here.     Q: What about strength overseas. Will that somehow offset any weakness in the U.S.?   A: It has to date. That has cushioned some of the U.S. slowdown. It is a new world with all the international activity. But when you look at valuations, there are not that many low-P/E stocks out there. As skeptics and contrarians, it makes us a little nervous that everything has gone up. The average utility today is selling at 17 times earnings. It only has a 3% dividend yield. In the late '90s, no one cared about yield. Now we've come full circle and there's a yield bubble. It is illustrated by all the closed-end funds that have come public in the last two or three years based on yield. There have been $4 billion and $5 billion funds raised in the last few months. Investors have been buying yield-oriented securities all over the globe regardless of valuation. What's driving REITs at this point? All these closed-end funds and new dividend-focused funds.     Q: What do you like?   A: ConocoPhillips [ticker: COP] is a big position for us. It trades at 7.5 times earnings and five times cash flow. It is cheap any way you look at it. Clearly non-OPEC oil has peaked. OPEC oil will peak probably around 2014-15. There is just not enough excess capacity out there. We think prices will stay in the $50 to $70 range as we go through this slowdown period. But we have such a low-turnover philosophy we are not going to try to get cute and sell them and buy them back a quarter or two later.     Q: What is penalizing ConocoPhillips at this point? Still suffering from its purchase of Burlington Resources?   A: Maybe a little bit. They bought it when natural gas was about $7.50 per Mcf [thousand cubic feet] and then gas prices immediately went down to $5.50 per Mcf and it looked like they had overpaid. Today, natural gas is close to $8. We don't think they overpaid because we are very bullish on natural gas longer term. We have been very fortunate not to have seen $15 natural gas. And even at $40 oil, these companies are huge free-cash-flow machines. But because oil has come down from a high of $78, touched $49 and $50 in January and is now back up to the mid $60s, investors have backed off the shares. They've missed the point that Conoco can literally buy back 10% of its shares a year. This year they are going to buy back 3 1/2% of the company.   There is a lot more money to be made in energy stocks. Contrast ExxonMobil [XOM] with Conoco. All the indexes and all the ETFs buy Exxon. Exxon has a 6% weighting in the Russell 1000 Value. But Exxon is selling at 13 times earnings and 10 times cash flow. You can buy Conoco at five times cash flow. You are not going to lose money in Exxon, but you are not going to make as much as you would by being more selective. We also like smaller exploration and production companies like Anadarko [APC], Devon [DVN] and Apache [APA]. Those companies probably will not be around a couple of years from now because they'll be taken out. If BP [BP] wants to increase their gas assets, they are going to look at Anadarko, for example. We are overweight the sector. At one point Anadarko was down 6% or 7% for the year, and we took advantage of that weakness and it is now back up 6% or 7% and positive for the year.     Q: What other names are on your hit parade?   A: Amgen [AMGN]. And we can talk about Pfizer all day.   Let's start with Amgen.   Amgen is a stock that is transforming itself into a Big Pharma. It's been in a transition phase, going from a strong growth stock to more of a value stock. We initiated a small position in the $60 range, figuring that was a reasonable valuation. Then the stock got hit with concerns about a couple of its anemia drugs for cancer patients and their use in off-label treatments. Now the government agency that oversees Medicare may restrict coverage for the anti-anemia drugs. The stock headed south, which has made it even more compelling. Clearly, there is no alternative to these drugs other than blood transfusions, and blood supplies are limited.   Talk more about the prospects for Amgen? We see it as an 8% to 10% grower going forward, which is good growth for us. It has a good pipeline. The threat of biogeneric drugs is probably five years away. Their balance sheet is extremely strong. Their net debt is minimal. They are buying back a lot of stock. They've had an R&D budget the last five years that's basically been double the general pharma population, and we think that's peaking. As that comes down it will help earnings out. It's the only stock in our portfolio that does not pay a dividend.     Q: Do you think they will pay a dividend?   A: Yes, eventually. We see the stock in the low 70s in the next couple of years, and you can buy it today for 54.     Q: And Pfizer?   A: Pfizer [PFE] is on sale, too. There is pressure for Pfizer to shore up its pipeline. The early- and mid-stage pipelines are OK. But there is enough pressure that they could easily go out and buy something. The impetus for more consolidation in the pharmaceutical space is that after June 30, 2008, the accounting rules will change, requiring these companies to amortize any acquired R&D. If you want to acquire something, you want to do it before June 30, 2008; otherwise you'll be amortizing the acquisition.     Q: What would you like to see Pfizer buy?   A: Wyeth [WYE] would be perfect for Pfizer, and we own that, as well. Wyeth has a great pipeline, but it's not quite as savvy on the drug-approval process. They take longer to get their drugs approved. Their distribution system isn't as good as Pfizer's. And they have less of a patent-expiration problem than any other Big Pharma. Pfizer is extremely cheap. We've been selling Merck and buying more Pfizer. I thought Merck [MRK] was worth 45 to 50 back when it was at 25, and today it is at 52. So it is fully valued.     Q: Where do you see Pfizer?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : FDA Issues Approvable Letter for SPD465 (Triple-Bead Mixed Amphetamine Salts) for the Treatment of ADHD in Adults
Story: BASINGSTOKE, United Kingdom, and PHILADELPHIA, May 19 /PRNewswire/ -- Shire plc (LSE: SHP; Nasdaq: SHPGY; TSX: SHQ) announced today that it has received an approvable letter from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for SPD465 (triple-bead mixed amphetamine salts [MAS], an investigational oral stimulant intended to provide symptom control of ADHD in adults for up to 16 hours with one daily dose.  Following receipt of this approvable letter, Shire is evaluating its options related to SPD465.     Shire submitted a New Drug Application for SPD465 on July 21, 2006.(1)  If approved, SPD465 will be a treatment option for adults with ADHD and part of Shire's overall ADHD portfolio.        About ADHD     Approximately 7.8 percent of all school-age children, or about 4.4 million U.S. children aged 4 to 17 years, have been diagnosed with ADHD at some point in their lives, according to the CDC.(2)  ADHD is one of the most common psychiatric disorders in children and adolescents.(3)  The disorder is also estimated to affect approximately 9.8 million adults across the U.S. based on a retrospective survey of adults aged 18 to 34, projected to the full U.S. adult population.(4,5)  ADHD is a neurobiological psychiatric disorder that manifests as a persistent pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity- impulsivity that is more frequent and severe than is typically observed in individuals at a comparable level of development.(6)  To be properly diagnosed with ADHD, a child needs to demonstrate at least six of nine symptoms of inattention; and/or at least six of nine symptoms of hyperactivity/impulsivity; the onset of which appears before age 7 years; that some impairment from the symptoms is present in two or more settings (e.g., at school and home); that the symptoms continue for at least six months; and that there is clinically significant impairment in social, academic or occupational functioning and the symptoms cannot be better explained by another psychiatric disorder.(6)     Although there is no "cure" for ADHD, there are accepted treatments that specifically target its symptoms.  The most common standard treatments include educational approaches, psychological or behavioral modification, and medication.(7)        For further information on ADHD please visit www.adhdsupport.com.        Shire ADHD Portfolio     In addition to SPD465, Shire's portfolio of ADHD treatments includes VYVANSE(TM) (lisdexamfetamine dimesylate), the first prodrug stimulant, which is planned to launch 2Q 2007, DAYTRANA(TM) (methylphenidate transdermal system), the first and only ADHD patch, and ADDERALL XR(R) (mixed salts of a single-entity amphetamine product), a long-acting formulated stimulant. SPD503 (guanfacine HCl extended release) is currently under review with FDA.        About SPD465     SPD465, a single entity formulation of mixed amphetamine salts, was designed to provide extended release of medication with symptom control for up to 16 hours, is being studied for the treatment of ADHD in adults. The most common adverse events reported include insomnia, decreased appetite, dry mouth, headache and weight decrease.        About VYVANSE and ADDERALL XR     Tell your doctor about any heart conditions, including structural abnormalities, that you, your child, or a family member, may have.  Inform your doctor immediately if you or your child develops symptoms that suggest heart problems, such as chest pain or fainting.     VYVANSE or Adderall XR should not be taken by patients who have advanced disease of the blood vessels (arteriosclerosis); symptomatic heart disease; moderate to severe high blood pressure; overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism); known allergy or unusual reactions to drugs called sympathomimetic amines (for example, pseudoephedrine); seizures; glaucoma; a history of problems with alcohol or drugs; agitated states; taken a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) within the last 14 days.     Tell your doctor before using, VYVANSE or Adderall XR if you or your child are being treated for or have symptoms of depression (sadness, worthlessness, or hopelessness) or bipolar disorder; have abnormal thoughts or visions, hear abnormal sounds, or have been diagnosed with psychosis; have had seizures or abnormal EEGs; have or have had high blood pressure; exhibit aggressive behavior or hostility.  Tell your doctor immediately if any of these conditions or symptoms develop while using VYVANSE or Adderall XR.     Abuse of amphetamines may lead to dependence.  Misuse of amphetamine may cause sudden death and serious cardiovascular adverse events.  These events have also been reported rarely with amphetamine use.     VYVANSE and Adderall XR were generally well tolerated in clinical studies. The most common side effects in studies of Vyvanse included: children - difficulty falling asleep, stomachache, and irritability. The most common side effects in studies of Adderall XR included: children  - decreased appetite, difficulty falling asleep, stomachache, and emotional lability; adolescents  - loss of appetite, difficulty falling asleep, stomachache, and weight loss; adults  - dry mouth, loss of appetite, difficulty falling asleep, headache, and weight loss.     Aggression, new abnormal thoughts/behaviors, mania, growth suppression, worsening of motion or verbal tics and Tourette's syndrome have been associated with use of drugs of this type.  Tell your doctor if you or your child have blurred vision while taking VYVANSE or Adderall XR.        About DAYTRANA     DAYTRANA should not be used in patients with allergy to methylphenidate or patch components; marked anxiety, tension and agitation; glaucoma; tics, diagnosis or a family history of Tourette's syndrome; seizures; or during or within 14 days after treatment with monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs).     Sudden death has been reported in association with CNS stimulant treatment at usual doses in children and adolescents with structural cardiac abnormalities or other serious heart problems. Sudden deaths, stroke, and myocardial infarction have been reported in adults taking stimulant drugs at usual doses in ADHD.  Physicians should take a careful patient history, including family history, and physical exam, to assess the presence of cardiac disease.  Patients who report symptoms of cardiac disease such as exertional chest pain and unexplained syncope should be promptly evaluated.  Use with caution in patients whose underlying medical condition might be affected by increases in blood pressure or heart rate.     New psychosis, mania, aggression, growth suppression, and visual disturbances have been associated with the use of stimulants.  Use with caution in patients with a history of: psychosis; EEG abnormalities; bipolar disorder; depression.  Growth and hematologic monitoring is advised during prolonged treatment.  Patients should avoid applying external heat to the DAYTRANA patch.  Skin irritation or contact sensitization may occur.     DAYTRANA should be given cautiously to patients with a history of drug dependence and alcoholism. Chronic abuse can lead to marked tolerance and psychological dependence.  Frank psychotic episodes can occur, especially with parenteral abuse. Careful supervision is required during withdrawal from     abusive use, since severe depression may occur.  Withdrawal following chronic therapeutic use may unmask symptoms of the underlying disorder.     Common adverse events reported by patients who received DAYTRANA in clinical trials were decreased appetite, insomnia, nausea, vomiting, decreased weight, tics, affect lability, and anorexia, consistent with adverse events commonly associated with the use of methylphenidate.     For further product information related to Shire's portfolio of ADHD treatments, please go to Vyvanse.com, AdderallXR.com and Daytrana.com.        Shire plc     Shire's strategic goal is to become the leading specialty biopharmaceutical company that focuses on meeting the needs of the specialist physician. Shire focuses its business on attention deficit and hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), human genetic therapies (HGT), gastrointestinal (GI) and renal diseases. The structure is sufficiently flexible to allow Shire to target new therapeutic areas to the extent opportunities arise through acquisitions. Shire believes that a carefully selected portfolio of products with a strategically aligned and relatively small-scale sales force will deliver strong results.     Shire's focused strategy is to develop and market products for specialty physicians. Shire's in-licensing, merger and acquisition efforts are focused on products in niche markets with strong intellectual property protection either in the US or Europe.     For further information on Shire, please visit the Company's website: www.shire.com.     "SAFE HARBOR" STATEMENT UNDER THE PRIVATE SECURITIES LITIGATION REFORM ACT OF 1995     Statements included herein that are not historical facts are forward- looking statements. Such forward-looking statements involve a number of risks and uncertainties and are subject to change at any time. In the event such risks or uncertainties materialize, Shire's results could be materially affected. The risks and uncertainties include, but are not limited to, risks associated with: the inherent uncertainty of pharmaceutical research, product development, manufacturing and commercialization; the impact of competitive products, including, but not limited to the impact of those on Shire's Attention Deficit and Hyperactivity Disorder ("ADHD") franchise; patents, including but not limited to, legal challenges relating to Shire's ADHD franchise; government regulation and approval, including but not limited to the expected product approval dates of SPD503 (guanfacine extended release) (ADHD) and SPD465 (extended release triple-bead mixed amphetamine salts) (ADHD); Shire's ability to secure new products for commercialization and/or development; Shire's ability to benefit from its acquisition of New River Pharmaceuticals Inc.; and other risks and uncertainties detailed from time to time in Shire plc's filings with the Securities and Exchange   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 11:10 ET (15:10 GMT)

Headline: : King Pharmaceuticals Reports Efficacy of ALTACE(R) 20mg And Efficacy of a Combination of ALTACE 20mg And Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg For 24-hour Blood Pressure Control
Story: BRISTOL, Tenn.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--May 19, 2007--   King Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (NYSE:KG) reported today that data from its Phase III clinical trial evaluating ALTACE(R) (ramipril) 20mg and the combination of ALTACE 20mg and hydrochlorothiazide (HCT) 25mg were presented this weekend at the American Society of Hypertension, Inc. (ASH) Twenty-Second Annual Scientific Meeting and Exposition (ASH 2007) in Chicago, Illinois. The clinical trial data showed that ALTACE 20mg resulted in significant reductions in systolic blood pressure (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP). ALTACE 20mg used in combination with HCT 25mg once daily as measured by a semi-automatic digital blood pressure device (office measurements) resulted in a statistically significant greater reduction of both seated DBP and seated SBP compared to monotherapy with HCT 25mg once daily or ALTACE 20mg once daily in patients with Stage 2 Essential Hypertension defined as blood pressure equal to or greater than 160 mmHg SBP or 100 mmHg DBP.     Data from the trial also showed that ALTACE 20mg monotherapy once daily provide significant reductions in mean 24-hour SBP and DBP of 11.4 mmHg and 6.2 mmHg, respectively. Importantly, as compared to office measurements, statistically significant greater reductions in mean 24-hour blood pressure, as measured by ambulatory blood pressure monitoring, were obtained with the combination therapy. Ambulatory blood pressure measurements have been shown to correlate better than office measurements for predicting adverse effects on end organs such as the kidney, heart, or brain. The safety profile of the combination was consistent with current labeling for the individual monotherapy drugs as approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA).     "As described in the current JNC-7 hypertension treatment guidelines, if SBP is 20 mmHg or DBP is 10 mmHg above a patient's goal, consideration should be given to initiating therapy with two antihypertensive drugs, one of which is usually a thiazide diuretic. In the study, combining ALTACE 20mg with HCT 25mg was significantly better than monotherapy in achieving blood pressure control. Our results also show that the maximum approved dose of 20mg a day of ALTACE was well tolerated and showed significant reductions in systolic and diastolic blood pressure," said Dr. William B. White, Professor and Chief of Hypertension and Clinical Pharmacology at the University of Connecticut Health Center, and the study's lead investigator. "These data provide evidence that ALTACE 20mg monotherapy and the combination of ALTACE 20mg with HCT 25mg provide meaningful clinical blood pressure reductions and 24-hour control."     "We're excited about the results of the study," said Dr. Eric Carter, Chief Science Officer of King. "These data demonstrate the efficacy and tolerability benefits of 20mg of ALTACE, the maximum approved dose, and the benefits of 20mg of ALTACE combined with HCT 25mg for patients who require an antihypertensive agent as well as a diuretic. We plan to submit these data as part of a New Drug Application to the FDA later this year, a major milestone for King Pharmaceuticals."       About the Clinical Trial     The primary endpoint of the trial was designed to demonstrate that the reduction in DBP in patients taking the combination of ALTACE 20mg and HCT 25mg once daily is statistically superior to that achieved in patients taking either monotherapy alone. The trial met the primary endpoint in that DBP reduction is statistically superior (p less than 0.001) with the combination compared to either monotherapy. The DBP was reduced by 15.5 mmHg with the combination compared to 8.5 mmHg with HCT 25mg and 9.2 mmHg with ALTACE 20mg.     A secondary endpoint of the trial was designed to demonstrate that the reduction in SBP in patients taking the combination of ALTACE 20mg and HCT 25mg once daily is statistically superior to that achieved in patients taking either monotherapy alone. The trial met the secondary endpoint in that SBP reduction is statistically superior with the combination compared to either monotherapy. The SBP was reduced by 18.6 mmHg with the combination compared to 11.5 mmHg with HCT 25mg (p less than 0.001) and 10.4 mmHg with ALTACE 20mg (p=0.002).     The clinical trial was a randomized, double-blind, double-dummy, parallel-arm, multicenter study evaluating the effects of combining ALTACE 20mg and HCT 25mg once a day versus the monotherapy comparator arms of the component drugs. Patients were treated for eight weeks. A total of 341 patients comprised the intention-to-treat efficacy population. Blood pressure was measured using both a semi-automatic digital blood pressure device and 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitor.     A copy of the poster detailing the results of the trial and presented at ASH 2007 is available on King's website at: http://www.kingpharm.com/ashposter.asp.       About ALTACE     ALTACE is the leading branded ACE inhibitor with multiple indications. ALTACE is indicated for the treatment of hypertension. ALTACE has also been shown to reduce the risk of death in stable patients who have demonstrated clinical signs of congestive heart failure within the first few days after sustaining acute myocardial infarction. Based upon the results of the landmark HOPE trial, ALTACE 10mg is also indicated in patients age 55 or over at high risk of developing a major CV event either because of a history of coronary artery disease, stroke or peripheral vascular disease or because of diabetes that is accompanied by at least one other CV risk factor (hypertension, elevated total cholesterol levels, low HDL levels, cigarette smoking, or documented microalbuminuria), to reduce the risk of stroke, myocardial infarction, or death from CV causes. ALTACE can be used in addition to other needed treatments (such as antihypertensive, antiplatelet or lipid-lowering therapies).     ALTACE should not be taken during pregnancy, as death or injury to an unborn child may result, or if serious side effects related to previous ACE inhibitors have occurred. Prescription ALTACE is not for everyone. ALTACE may cause swelling of the mouth, tongue, or throat, which could cause extremely serious risk and requires immediate medical care. ALTACE may lower blood sugar if taken for diabetes. A physician should be contacted if one experiences symptoms of low blood sugar such as sweating or shakiness. Common side effects include persistent dry cough, dizziness, and light-headedness due to low blood pressure.     For a copy of the ALTACE prescribing information, please visit http://www.altace.com/.       About Hydrochlorothiazide     Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used in the management of hypertension either alone or to enhance the effect of other antihypertensive drugs in the more severe forms of hypertension. It is contraindicated in patients with hypersensitivity to hydrochlorothiazide or other sulfonamide-derived drugs. It should be used with caution in patients with renal disease, impaired hepatic function or progressive liver disease, diabetes, gout or lupus erythematosus. Common side effects include dizziness, light-headedness, low blood pressure, dehydration and stomach irritation.       About King Pharmaceuticals     King, headquartered in Bristol, Tennessee, is a vertically integrated branded pharmaceutical company. King, an S&P 500 Index company, seeks to capitalize on opportunities in the pharmaceutical industry through the development, including through in-licensing arrangements and acquisitions, of novel branded prescription pharmaceutical products in attractive markets and the strategic acquisition of branded products that can benefit from focused promotion and marketing and product life-cycle management.       Forward-looking Statements     This release contains forward-looking statements which reflect management's current views of future events and operations, including, but not limited to, statements pertaining to the Company's plan to file a New Drug Application this year with respect to the combination. These forward-looking statements involve certain significant risks and uncertainties, and actual results may differ materially from the forward-looking statements. Some important factors which may cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements include dependence on King's ability to file the New Drug Application as planned; and dependence on the final outcome of the Company's review of the data. Other important factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements are discussed in the "Risk Factors" section and other sections of King's Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2006 and Form 10-Q for the quarter ended March 31, 2007, which are on file with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. King does not undertake to publicly update or revise any of its forward-looking statements even if experience or future changes show that the indicated results or events will not be realized. Headline: Barron's(5/21) How Clorox Could Clean Up -2-
Story: Says analyst Walter Scully of Putnam Investments, which bought Clorox shares late last year: "Clorox has gone through a couple of years of huge increases in raw materials costs, worse than anyone else's. Headline: Barron's(5/21) Building For The Future
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Dimitra DeFotis   USG, the largest North American maker of wallboard, has survived several hits from the wrecking ball. The company was pushed to seek bankruptcy protection in 2001 by the rising costs of asbestos litigation, only to emerge last year just as the housing market peaked. As new-home construction tanked, earnings fell to $8.85 a share, from $11.01 in 2005. This year and next, USG will be lucky to earn $2 a share, which helps explain why its stock price has plummeted by 48%, to 48.   Yet USG (ticker: USG), which makes and markets a wide range of building materials, could prosper mightily when the housing cycle turns. While 45% of its 2006 revenue of $5.8 billion was tied to new-home sales, 15% derived from residential remodeling and 40% from commercial construction -- both markets that continue to grow. In addition, USG is reducing wallboard output, developing new lines of business such as ceiling products, and enhancing its distribution system through savvy acquisitions. Not least, it is switching manufacturing to newer, low-cost facilities from older, less efficient plants.   John De Gan, chief investment officer of Harbor Advisory, says these and other moves will give the company "a higher market share with more pricing strength." Harbor has been buying the stock since March. De Gan calculates USG could earn $5 to $6 a share in three years (adjusting for the doubling of shares outstanding a result of an offering to help finance a $4 billion asbestos trust fund). If the stock were to sell again for 15 times future earnings -- its historic average -- it could command a price as high as 90.   USG trades for 25 times 2007 expected earnings. But history has shown the wisdom of buying cyclical stocks at peak multiples, before earnings start to rebound.   The Chicago company, once called U.S. Gypsum, owes a debt to its famous shareholder, Warren Buffett, whose support helped it raise the funds for the asbestos trust. Buffett first bought stock in 2000 and raised his stake last year. He now owns 17%. Buffett and USG have agreed that he must bid for the whole company if his holdings exceed 40% before 2013. Indeed, USG sometimes rallies on rumors that Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) is preparing an offer.   That hasn't happened yet, but other value investors climbed aboard in the first quarter: Ariel Capital Management added 3.4 million shares, Third Avenue Management bought 1.7 million shares and Wallace R. Weitz & Co. took on 1.3 million shares, according to filings. They, too, presumably recognize USG's operating leverage, and expect the stock to discount a housing recovery before it occurs.   USG has fared poorly relative to other building-materials suppliers, such as American Standard (ASD), Masco (MAS) and Owens Corning (OC), in part because of the wallboard market's deteriorating fundamentals. Demand is expected to fall 10% this year, and the company's average first-quarter selling price -- $164.12 per thousand square feet -- was 9% below its average price in '06. USG's Sheetrock brand has become a generic term for wallboard (which accounts for most of its revenue). The company has 30% of the market, ahead of privately held National Gypsum and Koch Industries' Georgia-Pacific.   In a bid to curb price erosion, the industry has shrunk capacity by roughly 20% from peak levels; USG has cut its output by 2.5 billion feet over last year. Yet, price weakness also creates "attractive growth opportunities for us, like acquisitions . . . in low-cost wallboard-manufacturing capacity," CEO William Foote told investors in April.   USG bought a gypsum-mining and plaster manufacturing company in Mexico, and its low-cost factories are humming. It has also invested $900 million-plus in the past five years to build some of the industry's most advanced production facilities and plans to bring them online in coming years in California, Virginia and Pennsylvania. USG similarly is investing in its fast-growing distribution arm, L&W Supply, which will allow it to boost sales for commercial customers. And it snapped up a California wholesaler in the first quarter that serves seven states and part of Mexico.   Housing bears see no end in sight to the industry's troubles, a view confirmed for many by Wednesday's news that the percentage drop in building permits represented a 17-year low. Yet doom, gloom and the nationwide glut of condos, colonials and McMansions are reflected in many housing-related shares. Either way, USG is likely to wind up a winner, given its thoughtful effort to remodel its own house when times are tough.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) Speaking Of Dividends: Heartland Express Adds A $2 Special Payout
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   After several years of meager dividends, cash-rich and debt-free Heartland Express is delivering. The short- to medium-haul truckload carrier (ticker: HTLD) Monday declared a special dividend of $2 a share, which is worth $197 million on its 98.3 million common shares outstanding. Disbursement is slated for May 30 to investors of record May 24. The stock will go ex-dividend May 22.   Founder and Chief Executive Russell A. Gerdin and his family own 40.5% of the Coralville, Iowa, company's common, and so will reap $80 million of the bonus.   Cash payouts were initiated in August 2003 at an adjusted penny a share and currently are two cents. A regular quarterly will be paid along with the bonus. There have been four stock splits since 2001. Traded on Nasdaq, Heartland set a 52-week high Tuesday of 18.92, putting the stock ahead 26% for the year to date.   Wachovia Capital Markets analyst Justin Yagerman said the special distribution makes sense because Heartland will have low capital expenditures this year after buying extra equipment last year ahead of new emissions regulations. "We view the special dividend as an attractive way for Heartland to return capital to shareholders," Yagerman wrote in a research note, although he doesn't expect other truckload carriers to follow suit. That's because none of Heartland's peers can boast such a large cash reserve-$365 million, or $3.72 a share, at March 31, and up $33.8 million from year-end 2006. He rates the stock Market Perform. By contrast, Bear Stearns' Edward Wolfe rates it Underperform, owing to currently sluggish freight demand and weak pricing. Standard & Poor's investment opinion is Hold.   With assets of $700.7 million, Heartland posted a 14% gain in first-quarter net from a year earlier, to $22.6 million, or 23 cents a share, on a 6% advance in operating revenues, to $143.4 million. The first quarter's net cash flow from operations was $34.1 million.   For the 22nd consecutive year, global-insurance and financial-services behemoth American International Group (AIG) is enriching its dividend. Wednesday New York City-based AIG boosted its quarterly common payout 21%, to 20 cents a share, from 16.5 cents.   Investors of record Sept. 7 will receive the new disbursement Sept. 21. The ex-dividend date is Sept. 5. Yield: 1.11%. Dividends have been paid without interruption since 1969.   A Dow industrials component, AIG shares currently change hands just a tad under their 52-week high of 72.97, set Dec. 18. During the first quarter of 2007, AIG repurchased 2.5 million shares of its common stock, and bought back an additional 6.6 million in April.   Controversial oilfield-services giant Halliburton (Barron's, Nov. 20, 2006) Wednesday hiked its common dividend for the second year in a row. The new quarterly will be nine cents a share, up 20% from 7.5 cents. The respective payment and record dates are June 21 and June 1; the ex-date is May 30. Dividends have been ongoing since 1947.   Trading on the Big Board a couple notches below its 52-week high of 38.82, the stock (HAL) yields 1%. Houston-based Halliburton has $1.6 billion remaining under its current stock-buyback program.   In the first quarter, 88-year-old Halliburton, once led by Vice President Dick Cheney, completed a spinoff of KBR, its engineering and construction unit, via a stock swap. KBR contracts awarded by the Pentagon and worth more than $19 billion -- making it the sole provider of food and housing to the military in Iraq and Afghanistan -- have drawn congressional scrutiny. Halliburton expects to post a divestiture-related gain of $1 billion in the second quarter.   North American food-and-drug retailing giant Safeway (SWY) sweetened its quarterly to 6.9 cents a share from 5.75 cents. The California-based company is now one of the nation's biggest buyers of clean energy, following the Golden State's 2000 energy crisis. As a result, it's been able to keep costs down. Profits are on the rise, reflecting the company's aggressive rollout of its "lifestyle" stores, which have decor and produce meant to help Safeway compete with grocers like Whole Foods.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) The Trader: Taking Aim At A Record S&P
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   Sometime soon -- possibly even this week  -- the stock market will ascend to a new peak, and this rabidly anticipated event will inspire much hope and hoopla. But a question emerges as the Standard & Poor's 500 closes in on its March 24, 2000, high: Will 1527.46 prove to be a finishing line that stocks stumble across before collapsing, or just another marker on their continuing marathon?   The fanfare grew louder Friday as the 500-stock benchmark pushed past 1520, and as the Dow Jones Industrial Average broke above 13,500 a mere 17 days after topping 13,000.   But even the cheering section can't fail to notice signs of fatigue. Stocks' advance has been stoic but has lacked oomph. Indexes made new highs on waning momentum and weakening volume, and the rally increasingly is led by large stocks, while technology and smaller companies lag.   Rising for the seventh straight week, the Dow gained 230 points, or 1.7%, to 13,557, yet another record close. The S&P 500 also climbed for a seventh straight week, adding 17 points, or 1.1%, and hitting a seven-year high at 1523.   One of the market's broadest benchmarks, the Dow Jones Wilshire 5000, also notched a record close. But the Nasdaq Composite Index fell for a second straight week and lost 4 points, or 0.1%, to 2558. The Russell 2000 index of small stocks retreated 6 points, or 0.7%, to 824.   Keeping larger stocks afloat were a raft of benign economic data. Gasoline prices hit a record national average of $3.09 a gallon early last week and continued climbing, and indicators forecasting economic activity declined more than analysts had expected. But the gloom was balanced by data pointing to slowing inflation, renewed manufacturing growth and a solid job market, with weekly unemployment claims falling for a fifth straight week to stay below 300,000.   Worries of consumer belt-tightening continue to bog down retailers, regional banks, and sectors that suffer in a domestic slowdown. But a steady stream of mergers reminded investors of the liquidity surfeit, including a potential $11 billion deal for General Electric's (ticker: GE) plastics division, and Microsoft's (MSFT) $6 billion cash offer for online advertising company aQuantive (AQNT).   But as the Dow eked out another record close Thursday, market breadth -- or the ratio of advancing stocks to declining ones at the New York Stock Exchange -- had turned negative. It was a sign of flagging momentum and had already occurred four times in the past month. Yet such combinations of a Dow record and flailing breadth tended to be rare historically and were seen just five other times since 1940. In four of those five prior examples, the Dow had declined by an average 2% a month later, notes Jason Goepfert of www.sentimentrader.com.   Last week, more than 56% of S&P 500 stocks were hovering within 5% of their 52-week highs. Continued short bets and vigilant option hedging suggest that few traders would be surprised if this extended market pulls back soon. But until the indexes violate their upward trend, the consensus seems to expect any correction to be short-lived and shallow.   So what might drive stocks higher in the longer term? Believe it or not, a first-quarter redux can't be ruled out, as projected second-quarter profits are hacked down to levels that companies could beat with ease.   First-quarter profits rose nearly 9%, well above the 3.6% analysts had penciled in, and that outperformance spurred bulls on.   As if (recent) history had taught us nothing, analysts once again are cutting second-quarter profit projections drastically enough to send projected S&P 500 growth to a measly 3.3%. That figure could still slip toward 2% this summer, says Brown Brothers Harriman strategist Brian Rauscher.   In fact, all 10 S&P 500 sectors are expected to post second-quarter profit growth in the single digits or less -- the first time in more than a decade for such pervasive pessimism. Specifically, profits are expected to increase 8.9% for consumer staple companies, 8.4% for industrials and 7.2% for health care, but to decline 3.7% for energy and 5.7% for consumer discretionary companies.   Low-ball estimates could "set the stage for another round of upside surprises," says Rauscher, who sees profits increasing 5% to 7% this quarter.   Sure, analysts in the Sarbanes-Oxley era have preferred to be caught by upside surprises than downside shocks. Others underestimate the impact of stock buybacks on per-share earnings, and the catalyst of the weaker greenback.   Then there is the increasingly dated and unreliable practice of using the U.S. economy to gauge U.S. company profits. Large U.S. companies increasingly are exposed to the faster growth of foreign economies; some 48% of S&P 500 profits were earned overseas last year -- up from 35% in 2002.   "Investors, however, are making the understandable mistake of equating foreign economic growth, and emerging-market growth especially, with the growth of foreign companies," argues Daniel Chung, Fred Alger Management's CEO and chief investment officer. It's a reason why growth-chasing investors are funneling money to foreign markets, and why "U.S.- listed companies are becoming more undervalued."     Unlike other financial stocks, those of life-insurance companies have enjoyed a good run lately. Agile capital management and growing variable products have helped offset the compressed spreads of fixed annuity offerings, and first-quarter profits have been strong.   Rising stock prices will buy management time. But many companies are sitting on a growing wad of cash, with total capital for U.S. life insurers increasing 20% last year to about $300 billion. The sector also is crowded and fragmented, and competition from alternative savings products increasingly rewards those with scale and reach.   Rob Haines, a senior analyst at the independent research firm CreditSights, is among those who expects more mergers as companies look to put money to work. Potential acquirers include American International Group (AIG), which ended last quarter with $15 billion to $20 billion in excess capital; Prudential Financial (PRU), which has a good merger track record and more than $6 billion in untapped debt capacity; and MetLife (MET), which until recently had been busy integrating its Travelers acquisition.   Screening for likely targets among companies with more than $10 billion in assets -- essentially those with attractive heft but which may lack the scale to compete in the long run -- Haines came up with names including Conseco (CNO), Phoenix (PNX), Protective Life (PL) and Unum Group (UNM). These stocks trade at 0.7 to 1.5 times book value and "could be fairly easy to digest by any one of the larger industry leaders," he notes.   Phoenix, for instance, could face mounting investor pressure to sell itself if the Hartford company fails to turn around its asset-management and life-insurance businesses. Its shares already reflect a takeover premium, but not everyone sees immediate takeout prospects. Morgan Stanley analyst Nigel Dally, for one, sees Phoenix using proceeds from a closed-block securitization to make its own acquisition, which could make it a less alluring target.   Conseco, which emerged from bankruptcy in 2003, has tended to attract hedge funds with an eye on value and a stomach for risk. The stock has slid 23% over the past two years, and the life and health insurer this month reported lower-than-expec ted first-quarter profits.   But at just 0.7 times book value, the stock offers an appealing risk-reward profile. It has improved claims management, and better cash flow has allowed it to buy back more shares. And "should the company fail in its attempts to solidify its fundamentals, we believe the company could emerge as a beneficiary of industry-wide consolidation," Dally notes.     What's not to like about bananas? The average banana has four times the protein of an apple, and five times the Vitamin A and iron. They're quick to eat, easy to digest, yummy enough to add to everything from breakfast to dessert. They also come with their own disposable packaging -- and in a sunny, happy color.   Still, Chiquita Brands International (CQB) has found a way to improve one of nature's perfect foods. Working with a small synthetic polymer company called Landec (LNDC), Chiquita is introducing "intelligent packaging" to extend the shelf life of ripe bananas by up to 12 days. This allows bananas to be sold more widely at convenience stores, fast-food restaurants and even a Starbucks near you. It is also rolling out new products like "Chiquita Fruit in a Bottle," which has snagged a 5% share in its first market, Belgium.   The push to transform the 107-year old company "from a commodity produce supplier to a more value-added, healthy consumer products company" bodes well for profit growth, says Oppenheimer analyst Barry Sine, who expects per-share earnings to double to $1.50 next year from 75 cents in 2007.   The push toward higher-premium products isn't new -- Chiquita bought the Fresh Express package salad business in 2005 -- but the rollout of new products has gathered steam lately. So has the rally in its shares, up 15% this month to about 17.   Today, bananas drive nearly three-quarters of Chiquita's revenue. But bananas have image problems: They brown quickly, bruise easily and are difficult to transport and store. While international growth is robust, sales in the mature U.S. market are up just 5% since 2001.   Enter Landec's permeable polymer, which allows oxygen to enter the package and carbon dioxide to leave to extend freshness. Hoping that Americans will eat more bananas if they're fresher and more available, Chiquita has been testing individually cut and packaged bananas at some 8,500 locations, such as 7-Eleven and Cumberland Farms stores. It also is selling bananas in sealed packages of threes. Because these fetch higher prices, but don't cost more to grow, margins are better. Chiquita's grand plan: rolling out these new products at 200,000 non-traditional outlets.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Salad profits also were hurt by an e. coli scare last fall, and will take time to recover. But given the steps that Chiquita is taking to reduce profit volatility, Oppenheimer's Sine reckons that the company's shares are worth 22.   Separately, Landec shares have climbed steadily to about 13.25, up 512% since 2003, as the Menlo Park, Calif., company worked off its debt, improved profits and boosted its cash stash to more than $2.25 a share.   Talk about enjoying the fruits of your labors!   ---   E-mail: kopin tan@barrons.com   ---                  VITAL SIGNS                                Friday's        Week's     Week's                                 Close        Change     % Chg. Headline: Barron's(5/21) How Clorox Could Clean Up
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Leslie P. Norton   This week, Clorox shareholders hope to learn how their company, which operates largely in North America's mature markets, plans to boost its growth.   Thursday, the household-products maker will unveil its long-term strategy at an analysts' meeting in New York. The stakes are high for CEO Donald Knauss, the former Coca-Cola executive who took Clorox's helm in October, after a heart attack led Gerald Johnston to resign. For some time, an outside consultant has pored over Clorox's product portfolio and operations. Speculation that the company will act on the consultant's recommendations, which could include jettisoning some brands and focusing on growth abroad, recently helped push Clorox shares to an all-time high of $68.50. Late Friday, they were around 67.   Already, there's encouraging evidence that the Oakland, Calif.-based producer of bleach, Glad bags, Kingsford charcoal and Hidden Valley salad dressings is capable of delivering solid earnings gains.   This month, Clorox (ticker: CLX) reported surprisingly strong profits for its fiscal third quarter, ended in March. Net came in at 84 cents a share, versus 72 cents a year earlier, amid good volume growth in home-care products and cat litter. For the year, Clorox expects its sales to climb "about 5%," to $4.88 billion. It also foresees earnings near $3.21 to $3.27 a share, versus $2.90 last year. For its next fiscal year, ending in June 2008, Wall Street's consensus forecast puts profit at $560 million, or $3.68 a share, and sales at $5.1 billion or more.   Earnings could go even higher if raw-material costs wane and if Clorox begins initiatives -- people who know the company well believe it will -- aimed at energizing growth and bolstering its exposure overseas. Clorox declined to make Knauss or other executives available to Barron's before Thursday's meeting.   The company's gross margins were hit hard in recent years by rising tabs for the polyethylene used in bottles, bags and wraps. At the same time, the price of diesel fuel jumped, hiking product-transportation costs. Last year, Clorox's gross margin clocked in at 42.2%, down from as much as 46.3% in 2003. "Over the past four years," observes John Faucher, a JPMorgan analyst, "this company lost 1,000 basis points [10 percentage points] of gross margin, owing to increased raw-materials costs." Clorox held its ground, partly by raising prices.   Clorox earned $2.90 a share last year, before extraordinary items, about flat with 2005 results. Now, earnings are beginning to strengthen again. Nobody expects raw-material costs to moderate steeply. But, bulls on the stock point out, put a more normal number on earnings -- say $4 -- and a multiple in the mid-to-high teens, and you get a stock price in the mid-70s.   "The investment case, pure and simple, is that it has a very defensible business model," says Bob Goldsborough, who oversees the Clorox position at Ariel Capital Management in Chicago. "The bear case was angst over raw materials. Clorox has responded clearly by innovating and implementing price increases. They're not going to give that back." Goldsborough figures the stock is worth $85, 30% above its recent level, assuming 3.5% annual revenue growth over the next five years, margin gains and 10% earnings growth.   So what to expect from Thursday's confab?   First, a plan to boost business overseas. Today, 85% of Clorox's sales come from the U.S. and Canada, both mature markets -- markets that Clorox dominates. Despite its paltry $10 billion market value, Clorox represents 20% of all dollar sales in its categories, second only to P&G.   Given the dollar's current weakness, currency translations alone could boost returns for Clorox's competitors. In the March quarter, a chunk of rival Colgate-Palmolive's (CL) sales growth came from the strong euro, but Clorox has no presence in the euro zone. Double-digit sales growth in emerging markets has countered softness in developed markets for Kimberly-Clark (KMB) in recent years. And, Lehman Brothers reckons, the third world will account for at least half of the organic growth at Procter & Gamble (PG).   A survey by A.C. Nielsen last year of emerging middle classes showed that two-thirds of dollar growth in consumer products comes from developing markets. Most in demand: disinfectant and garbage bags. "This is the price of admission to the middle class, and Clorox is a sleeping giant; these guys are uniquely positioned to capitalize on this fast-growing consumer-products category," says Liz Crawford, a consumer-products strategist at Iconoculture.   Clorox has begun augmenting its nascent position in emerging markets, with a recent acquisition vaulting it into the No. 1 spot among bleach suppliers in Ecuador, the Dominican Republic, Venezuela, Colombia, Uruguay and Canada. During the third quarter, the company's international operations sported 16% sales growth, versus 5% to 7% for the domestic units. "The raw-materials easing has given Knauss the flexibility to put his stamp on the company," says JPMorgan's Faucher. "I'd like to see them buy small local players in household cleaning internationally, in Latin America, Asia, emerging markets."   Another goal of the strategy that will be outlined Thursday will be to find more "gamechangers." Clorox uses the term to define a new product category that creates demand. That's important in a mature market, where competition can savage pricing. Gamechangers boost market share and command prices well above those of private-label brands. In North America, Clorox faces many formidable rivals, ranging from privately held S.C. Johnson, which sells Pledge, Drano and Ziploc bags, to publicly traded Prestige Brands (PBH), which sells Comet, Pactiv (PTV), which sells Hefty bags, to Alcoa (AA), which produces Reynolds Wrap. The toughest competition comes from private-label brands focused on price and volume.   In recent years, Clorox's stable of gamechangers has included Glad Press 'n Seal wrap -- a solid success that seized market share -- and Glad ForceFlex, a diamond-patterned trash bag that stretches without tearing, accommodating awkward items. There was also a nice twist on the razor-and-blades model: the ToiletWand, with a replaceable cleaning head.   But some promising gamechangers haven't lived up to the name. Among them: the BathWand and Clorox Anywhere, a sanitizing spray. Two years ago, Clorox ran a contest for America's dirtiest desk, and discovered that desks harbor more germs than toilet seats. Yet Clorox Anywhere -- which claims to be both effective and safe around food -- wasn't a big hit. Says a former competitor: "Consumers feel weird about spraying bleach all over the place. There's efficacy and safety -- and people have a hard time reconciling the two."   Last month, Clorox, which will celebrate its centennial in 2013, launched a Clorox Anywhere hand-sanitizing spray aimed at businesses. It could be a tough sell: Since 2000, according to Productscan Online, 67 such products have been introduced, and Lysol and Purell dominate the market. "They need to get their product-development effort back on track," Ariel's Goldsborough says of Clorox. "Management is sorry they developed the term gamechangers because investors focus so much on it. But to have momentum, you need to show progress to investors."   Some new products will be obtained through acquisitions. Clorox's debt is now just twice earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, and the company's stated goal of 3% to 5% growth excludes acquisitions. After Clorox reported third-quarter earnings, Knauss told analysts: "We have significant free cash flow and will be more aggressive."   One hot category that's ripe for expansion: nontoxic, biodegradable "green" products. "Sustainability is the mood of the moment," says Iconoculture's Crawford. Among the purveyors: Caldrea, a Minneapolis company started in 2000 that sells upscale cleaning products in nontoxic formulas; Method Products, a San Francisco eco-cleaning-product purveyor begun by a designer and an engineer and dubbed the seventh fastest-growing company in America by Inc. Magazine; and Mrs. Meyers, supplier of "aromatherapeutic" household-cleaning items plugged by Oprah. All three companies are still held by the entrepreneurs who founded them.   Also Thursday, Clorox might indicate that it eventually will sell some brands. Colgate might serve as a model, Lehman Brothers suggests; Colgate, which has refocused on core product lines such as oral care, generated nearly three times as much revenue last year as Clorox did, with only two-thirds as many product categories. Kimberly-Clark, 3 1/2 times Clorox's size, competes in half the categories.   Clorox has 17 business lines, not all of which make sense grouped together. Its largest businesses -- Kingsford charcoal, Clorox and Glad -- dominate their markets. However, the company is fighting pitched battles in trash bags, disposable storage containers and storage bags, cat litter (Fresh Step and Scoop Away), drain openers (Liquid Plumr), and home-cleaning products (Tilex, Formula 409). The real opportunity is grabbing share from the category that pollsters call "all other manufacturers." This group sells 51% of auto-care products, 35% of disposable food-storage containers and 24% of liquid cleaners, Lehman reports.   What Clorox brands might go on the block? Although food sports fat margins, the possible candidates include Hidden Valley salad dressings and K.C. Masterpiece barbecue sauces, which together account for 8% of Clorox's revenue. Then there's S.O.S. scouring pads and Lestoil cleaner. The former faces strong competition from Scotch-Brite, made by 3M (MMM), and Lestoil sales slid 12% from 2003 to 2006. Another "problem child," Lehman writes, is Brita, the water-purification operation, which has had to offer average 13% discounts from list prices and has been hurt by bottled water's popularity.   In short, although Clorox officials are being tight-lipped pending Thursday's meeting, the company is poised to rejigger itself to generate greater returns.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
