Headline: Barron's(5/21) Up & Down Wall Street: The View From Mars
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Alan Abelson   Were the proverbial little green man from Mars to descend on this hurting planet, he could be forgiven for believing he had landed in a nest of vipers feeding on calumny.   Alan Greenspan signs on as an economic consultant with bond maven Bill Gross' Pimco. Instead of congrats and hurrahs, the news is greeted by the notion that Bill, who has gathered up a dazzling array of investment tools to help him and his crew divine the next move in interest rates, has finally nailed what he has always been looking for, but until now has been unable to find -- a reliable contrary indicator.   Alberto Gonzales visits the ailing attorney general, John Ashcroft, in the hospital. Convinced that what Ashcroft needs most is a counter-irritant to keep his mind off his pain, Alberto urges him to approve what Ashcroft has been vehemently opposed to -- Uncle Sam indulging in illegal wiretapping. And, miraculously, it works: Ashcroft is so agitated that he forgets his aches and pains (he even forgets to thank Alberto). But instead of earning the nation's gratitude, Gonzales is broadsided by accusations that he sought to take advantage of Ashcroft's diminished capacities.   After four years and enormous expenditure of blood and treasure, Mr. Bush has finally hit upon the answer to the mess in Iraq: He somehow neglected to appoint a "war czar." Better late than never, we say, but here, too, the popular reaction is not joy but a sour complaint: Decades of having a "drug czar" hadn't made much of a dent in our drug problem, and the guy who was the "home security czar" was obviously out to a very long lunch when that hurricane hit New Orleans. For that matter, Russia had real honest-to-goodness czars aplenty and look where it ended up.   Congress, a very excitable bunch, is up in arms because around 80% of American software sold in China is counterfeited by the locals. You'd think our solons wouldn't be so darn nitpicky and concentrate on the tremendous progress the Chinese have been making in respecting other folks' property: spitting on the sidewalk, even if the sidewalk's owned by an American company, is no longer legal. And look at it this way: A full 20% of American software sold in China isn't counterfeit.   Disclosure that the hordes of candidates vying for the presidential nomination don't have to worry about where their next meal is coming from prompts not approbation but sneers. Rudy Giuliani, for example, took home over $11 million last year from giving speeches. Rudy happens to be a very fast talker. The poor man's rich man, John Edwards, drew a neat $1.7 million from a hedge fund in '06, where his job was to learn about finance (since he already has accumulated a tidy $30 million, we'd say ignorance is bliss). Besides, anything that keeps them off the streets is all to the good.   Paul Wolfowitz gets into hot water at the World Bank for trying to help a damsel in distress. The damsel happened to be an acquaintance. Well, actually a friend. In truth, his girlfriend. But he did for her no more than he'd do for any damsel in distress: find her a nice cushy job with a fat salary at the State Department, which specializes in nice cushy jobs with a fat salary. Alas, far from being rewarded for his chivalry -- can you believe this? -- he gets sacked as head of the bank.   We fervently urge President Bush to do the right thing here. Appoint Wolfowitz's girlfriend as the new head of the World Bank (she used to work there, so she knows the essentials: how to punch in and where the water cooler is) and fill the vacancy her leaving would create at the State Department by naming Wolfowitz to fill the post (which, given the paycheck it provides, must be vital).   That little green man from Mars, of course, wouldn't be shocked by everything he observes. He'd be sure to get a real charge out of the true wonder of the world -- the stock market -- and enjoy its thrilling ascent to the heavens, paced by the Dow Jones industrials (the only stock index the Martians follow). Even without his extraterrestrial powers of perception, he'd likely notice that the bulk of the market lately has been lagging, often a sign of trouble ahead. But, like everyone else, we imagine he's fully invested and not inclined to give it a moment's thought.   Although it may seem that way, not everyone in the universe is a raging bull. The odd exceptions are worth noting because they include people who presumably have some feel for corporate prospects -- namely, corporate insiders. The reasons that move a director or an officer to sell his company's stock may be various, but they rarely include expectations that the stock will go up.   What reminds us of that eternal truism is the latest issue of Crosscurrents, a very worthwhile stock-market newsletter put out by Alan Newman. Every now and then, Alan tallies insider buys and sells, either for the market as a whole or for a specific sector. In his most recent issue, he turns the spotlight on semiconductors, where he finds the sentiment of the folks supposedly in the know startlingly bearish.   More specifically, in the six months through May 2, among the top 10 chip makers he records 100 sales, totaling 3.75 million shares, compared with one solitary purchase of 500 shares. Alan notes that these ratios of sales-to-buys and the number of shares sold to the number bought were simply the worst ever. And he adds, "if 7,507 shares are sold for each share purchased, how much promise can this industry hold for investors?" No prizes awarded for guessing the answer to that question.   The chip stocks fetch something north of 22 times earnings and five times sales. Why a cyclical industry bereft of significant growth is endowed with such rich multiples is a puzzle to Alan, more symptomatic of speculative ebullience than value. And he rates the Semiconductors HOLDRs Trust (ticker: SMH) as an inviting short.   Frankly, we had never heard of QB Partners until last week when a rather lengthy report bearing their imprimatur entitled, "The Value of the Dollar" popped up in our e-mail. QB Partners, we can tell you thanks to our research chief, Pauline Yuelys, is a brand-new hedge fund (it was launched earlier this year), run by a couple of guys named Lee Quaintance and Paul Brodsky, both of whom have been on the Street for a spell.   Whatever their provenance, they've crafted a quite interesting analysis of what ails the dollar and why what ails it isn't anything trivial or transient. In fact, they see nothing but mournful things ahead for the buck, including, ultimately, its fall from grace as the world's reserve currency.   Basically, they size up the dilemma confronting our "policymakers" as whether to tighten the monetary and credit screws to bolster the dollar or to open them up even further to support asset prices. They have no doubts as to the resolution: The folks in charge will continue to do what they've always done -- "inflate the money supply and promote more credit, thereby sustaining asset prices at the expense of the purchasing power of the dollar."   That may seem the downward path to financial and eventually economic rack and ruin. But such a trivial consideration has never deterred Washington. You don't have to swallow whole QB Partners' gloomy diagnosis and prognosis for the beleaguered buck to find it valuable as well as provocative. Even though we agree there's plenty of sliding room left for the greenback, we're not convinced the outlook is as apocalyptic as the duo contends.   The report itself is nicely, almost elegantly, crafted, although at times it lapses into a kind of faux erudition, a tendency compounded somewhat by windy footnotes. Nonetheless, unlike so much of the tomes turned out by Wall Street, it's very much worth reading.   We obviously lack the space to do anything like justice to Quaintance and Brodsky's artful argument. What we'd like to share with you are a couple of the more pertinent points they raise.   The pair point out that the vigorous monetary inflation manifest in the 30% decline in the value of the dollar in the foreign-exchange markets since 2002 is seeping inexorably into the economy: "Prices paid in the U.S. for goods, services, financial assets, real-estate assets and natural resources have risen in recent years significantly more than population growth and organic demand."   They then cite the findings of Shadow Government Statistics, an independent research outfit, that "U.S. prices have been increasing at annual rates ranging from 8% to 11% since 1996. This contrasts with the Bureau of Labor Statistics' core CPI, which has risen in the 1.5% to 4.5% area."   And they comment drily that most Americans likely "intuit their rate of inflation more in line with the higher 'unofficial' rate than" the conveniently low numbers calculated by the BLS.   Timely, too, is their take on our increasingly leveraged markets, the inevitable result of all that cash and credit the government is so sedulously pumping into the economy. "Levered funding," they warn, "gives the public markets an embedded tendency to fall faster and harder than they otherwise would."   Leverage, they point out, enters markets leisurely but can exit quickly and violently. Might keep that in mind when some shill next tells you there's just too much liquidity around for stocks to ever go down.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Macquarie Power & Infrastructure Income Fund Announces Mailing Of Take-Over Bid Circular>MPT.UN.T
Story: TORONTO, ONTARIO--(CCNMatthews - May 18, 2007) - Macquarie Power & Infrastructure Income Fund (TSX:MPT.UN) ("MPT" or the "Fund") today announced it has mailed a take-over bid circular dated May 18, 2007 (the "Circular") to unitholders ("CPIF Unitholders") of Clean Power Income Fund (TSX:CLE.UN) (TSX:CLE.DB) ("CPIF") and holders of CPIF's 6.75% convertible debentures (the "Debentures"). MPT previously announced its offer to purchase (the "Offer"), subject to certain terms and conditions, all of CPIF's outstanding trust units ("CPIF Units"), including CPIF Units that may become issued and outstanding upon the conversion of the Debentures after the date of the Offer and prior to the expiry of the Offer.    MPT has filed the Circular and related documents with the various Canadian securities regulatory authorities. MPT's Offer will be open for acceptance until 12:01 a.m. (Toronto time) on June 23, 2007, unless withdrawn, varied or extended.    The package mailed to CPIF Unitholders and holders of Debentures includes the trustees' circular dated May 18, 2007 (the "Trustees' Circular") prepared by the Board of Trustees of CPIF's operating trust, on behalf of CPIF, which unanimously recommends that CPIF Unitholders accept the Offer and deposit their CPIF Units under the Offer.    Under the Offer, CPIF Unitholders are entitled to receive 0.5581 trust units of MPT ("MPT Units") and one contingency value receipt (a "CVR") for each CPIF Unit that is validly deposited and not validly withdrawn under the Offer.    The CVRs represent a contingent right of the holders to receive an amount calculated on the basis of 80% of the balance, if any, less certain costs and expenses, of US$7.593 million deposited in an escrow account established by PEET U.S. Holdings Inc. ("PEET"), currently a subsidiary of CPIF, in connection with its sale of Gas Recovery Systems, LLC ("GRS"), and payments, if any, that might be made by the purchaser of GRS to PEET if the purchaser receives certain refunds from Commonwealth Edison Co. relating to GRS (after certain specified adjustments and deductions for certain payments, claims, costs and expenses).    The Offer is subject to customary conditions, including that greater than 66 2/3% of the CPIF Units that are issued and outstanding at the expiry of the Offer are validly deposited and not validly withdrawn under the Offer.    CPIF Unitholders are urged to read the Circular, the Trustees' Circular and related documents. Questions regarding the Offer and requests for assistance in depositing CPIF Units under the Offer may be directed to Georgeson, the Information Agent for the Offer, at 100 University Avenue, 11th Floor, South Tower, Toronto, Ontario, M5J 2Y1, or toll free within North America at 1-866-682-6164. Copies of the Circular, the Trustees' Circular and other materials related to the Offer may be obtained without charge from Computershare Investor Services Inc., the Depositary for the Offer, at 100 University Avenue, 9th Floor, Toronto, Ontario, M5J 2Y1, Attention: Corporate Actions, or toll free within North America at 1-800-564-6253 or by email at corporateactions@computershare.com. Additionally, all materials related to the Offer are available on SEDAR at www.sedar.com.    CPIF Unitholders resident in the United States who deposit their CPIF Units under the Offer will not be entitled to receive MPIIF Units or CVRs. Instead, the MPIIF Units otherwise distributable to U.S. Unitholders will be aggregated and sold outside the U.S., through the facilities of the TSX, through a registered broker or investment dealer. Each Unitholder whose MPIIF Units have been sold in such manner will be forwarded an amount equal to such Unitholder's pro rata interest in the net proceeds of such sale or sales, after commissions, expenses and any applicable withholding taxes, as soon as reasonably practicable after completion of such sale or sales. In addition, the CVRs otherwise distributable to U.S. Unitholders will be issued to an escrow agent until payment on the CVRs, if any, is made, at which time each such Unitholder will be forwarded payment in an amount equal to such Unitholder's pro rata portion of the payment amount, if any, net of all costs related to such arrangements and any applicable withholding taxes.    This news release is not a solicitation of a proxy from any security holder of CPIF, nor is it an offer to purchase or a solicitation of an offer to sell securities.    About Macquarie Power & Infrastructure Income Fund    Macquarie Power & Infrastructure Income Fund invests in infrastructure assets with an emphasis on power infrastructure. MPT's strategy is to acquire and actively manage a high-quality portfolio of long-life infrastructure assets to improve their financial performance and provide growing and sustainable distributions to unitholders for the long term. MPT's infrastructure portfolio includes Cardinal, a 156MW gas-fired cogeneration power station in Ontario, and a 45% indirect interest in Leisureworld Senior Care LP, a leading long-term care provider in Ontario with over 30 years operating experience. MPT is managed by a wholly-owned subsidiary of Macquarie Bank Limited and a member of the Macquarie group. Please visit www.macquarie.com/mpt for additional information.    About Clean Power Income Fund    Clean Power Income Fund is an open-ended investment trust that is invested in 15 power generating facilities located in Quebec, Ontario, Alberta, British Columbia and four U.S. states with a total capacity of 303 MW. Three environmentally preferred technologies - windpower, waterpower and biomass - deliver electricity almost exclusively under long-term sales contracts and at minimal to zero fuel cost. CPIF is the first income fund to be certified under the Government of Canada's Environmental Choice(M) Program. More information about Clean Power Income Fund can be found at www.cleanpowerincomefund.com. Headline: Barron's(5/21) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited by Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     General Motors   -- GM-NYSE     Outperform   -- Price 29.46 on May 15   by Bear Stearns     Upgrading to Outperform from Peer Perform, setting a year-end 2008 price target of $35 based on 8 times our '09 earnings per share estimate of $4.35. Four factors drive our upgrade: 1) We view the Chrysler sale news as favorable for GM and Ford [and] are favorably impressed with United Auto Workers' . . . evenhanded initial response . . . 2) the Ford family is [reportedly] weighing the sale of a part of its controlling stake in the auto maker . . . 3) As illustrated on GM's 1Q report, the stock also appears to be back-trading more off auto news than GMAC's subprime mortgage results (i.e., stock held up on weak GMAC numbers on May 2, sold off May 3 when auto results were out) . . . 4) at 29.46, the stock [has] repeat-tested and found technical support.     Humana   -- HUM-NYSE     Underweight   -- Price 65.33 on May 15   by Prudential Securities     Humana misconduct highlighted by Oklahoma commission: Momentum is building to put in tighter controls around Medicare Advantage marketing practices as the states and [Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services] uncover abuses . . . stories noting senior-targeted hard-sell tactics . . . appear to be gaining political steam. . . . Possible restrictions could include greater compliance oversight, auditing procedures and commission guidelines. All of these could result in slower sales and greater administrative costs for MA. Target: 50; '07 price/earnings ratio: 16.5 times.     Idera Pharmaceuticals   -- IDP-Amex     Buy   -- Price 8.81 on May 15   by Merriman Curhan Ford & Co.     We believe current share price does not adequately account for Idera's industry-leading drug-discovery program, rapidly progressing clinical studies [in oncology and hepatitis-C treatments] . . . or potential for royalty-revenue generation. . . . The loss per share for 1Q was (12 cents) versus our estimate (24 cents) . . . Our loss-per-share estimates for 2Q, 3Q, 4Q, fiscal-year 2007 and FY08 have been changed to (26 cents), (30 cents), (14 cents), (83 cents) and (84 cents) from (22 cents), (23 cents), (20 cents), (89 cents), and (92 cents), respectively. Our revenue estimates for 4Q, FY07, and FY08 have been changed to $900,000, $4.3 million, and $6.5 million from $780,000, $3.2 million, and $4.7 million, respectively. Market cap: $186.8 million. . . . Idera is expected to initiate two combination-therapy oncology clinical programs in 2007.     Nokia   -- NOK-NYSE     Buy/Aggressive   -- Price 25.96 on May 15   by A.G. Edwards     NOK [announced] an improved outlook for June quarter. It expects to gain share in the wireless-handset market . . . [and] has made progress working through excess inventory. Estimated five-year EPS compound annual growth rate, 12%. Reiterating Buy; raising 12-to-18-month price objective to 31.     Sonic Foundry   -- SOFO-NNM     Buy   -- Price 2.46 on May 15   by Cantor Fitzgerald     The rich media-collaboration market [combining Web-streaming hardware, software and services with content-management] is still quite small. In our view, Sonic Foundry is leading this market across the technology-adoption chasm. We believe this market could grow to $1 billion within a decade. Despite focus on transitioning from small one-off sales to large enterprise contracts for next few quarters, we still expect healthy top-line sales growth of 41% in FY07, accelerating to 53% in FY08. Market cap: $87 million.     Suntrust Banks   -- STI-NYSE     Hold   -- Price 87.86 on May 15   by Sandler O'Neill     STI announced several initiatives designed to enhance shareholder value. Specifically, these initiatives include: 1) 33% higher efficiency and productivity targets 2) the sale of 9% of the company's Coca-Cola (KO) stock holdings 3) further capital optimization. Overall, we view these announcements as a net positive for the bank. After adjusting our EPS estimates for the aforementioned items, we are increasing our 2007 EPS estimate by 7 cents to $5.84 and increasing 2008 EPS estimate by 30 cents, to $6.75. We are increasing our 12-month price target by $4 to $88, mainly to reflect our higher EPS estimates. [With] limited upside to our target, we still feel Hold is appropriate rating.     Whole Foods Market   -- WFMI-NNM     Sell   -- Price 41.15 on May 15   by Zacks Investment Research     2Q results fell short of our estimates. The shortfall was due to lower-than-expected sales growth. We are again lowering our EPS estimates for fiscal 2007 and 2008 to reflect the company's deteriorating fundamentals . . . [and] the Federal Trade Commission is giving Whole Foods' acquisition of Wild Oats more scrutiny. We believe WFMI shares should trade at a multiple that more appropriately reflects a grocer with declining earnings growth. Our target price is 30, about 20 times our FY2008 EPS estimate. Maintain Sell.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) Barron's Online: Circling 3Com
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tiernan Ray   Citadel Investment Group, a $13 billion Chicago hedge-fund firm, has cemented its place in the growing ranks of activist investors with its recent purchase of 3Com shares, complete with an offer to provide "input" to turn the computer-networking company around.   That 3Com (ticker: COMS) needs turning around is clear: The Marlborough, Mass., concern lost its way in the dot-com years, pursuing a series of misguided acquisitions in a bid to become a consumer-electronics company. As its core Ethernet-switch business eroded, its shares fell to 4.60 from a peak of 100 in 2000. Today 3Com is a veritable pygmy alongside networking giant Cisco Systems (CSCO), with a market capitalization of $1.8 billion compared with Cisco's $159 billion.   The challenges facing 3Com, however, may be more than Citadel can fix. It will be tough for the company to achieve sustained sales growth and profitability in a market where even Cisco is finding such gains elusive. Also, 3Com's move to take sole control of a joint venture in China has left it with a strained balance sheet and little cash.   "It's difficult to see what Citadel could do better than management," says Mark Mowrey of Al Frank Asset Management in Laguna Beach, Calif. The firm owns 3Com and isn't selling, but Mowrey advises against putting new money into the stock.   3Com's attraction for Citadel likely relates to the company's China venture, H3C, which it formed in 2003 with networking-equipment vendor Huawei Technologies. H3C now generates 60% of sales. Citadel didn't return Barron's calls.   3Com sells mostly Ethernet switches, a hardware device used in computer networks to direct the flow of data. Emerging markets such as China are the new frontier for networking, as for many other businesses. Even so, it will be hard for 3Com to regain lost ground. Excluding H3C, its market share in so-called stackable Ethernet switches, has plummeted to 4% from 11% in 2001. Cisco boasts 70%, says Seamus Crehan, senior director of Ethernet-switch research for Dell'Oro Group.   "Restarting a networking business is not like playing T-ball with your kids, where you get an infinite number of retries," says Joe Skorupa, a research vice president at Gartner. But 3Com CEO Edgar Masri expects some improvement following the company's decision last year to buy out Huawei's stake in H3C. 3Com can hire top talent in China at a fifth of Western rates, which means it can be competitive on pricing, Masri says. In addition, as Ethernet switches incorporate more software features, such as network security, 3Com's strong sales in related security devices offer a distinct advantage.   Skeptics such as Kaufman Brothers analyst Manuel Recarey say 3Com's split from Huawei cost it a key distributor in China, which could lead to a sharp drop in sales growth. Worse, Huawei could emerge as a competitor in a year or two.   Short of buying Ethernet switches, it's hard to see how Citadel, which owns 8%, can grow 3Com in the near-term. It could agitate for a sale of the company, but with the stock up about 30% since March, there's scant value left in the shares.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Yum! Brands Expanding Deal With Florida Farmworkers >YUM
Story: IMMOKALEE, Fla. (AP)--Taco Bell owner Yum! Brands Inc. (YUM) has expanded its tomato deal with a Florida farmworker group to cover all of its restaurant chains, including Pizza Hut, Long John Silver's and A-and-W All-American Food Restaurants.   Under a previous agreement, Taco Bell agreed to pay a penny more per pound for its tomatoes, an increase passed along to tomato pickers in Immokalee. Yum! began the wider program several months ago but announced the change at its shareholders meeting Thursday.   McDonald's Corporation also agreed to a similar deal with the Coalition of Immokalee Workers.   Taco Bell buys roughly 110 million pounds a year at about $100,000.   The Louisville-based Yum!'s other chains buy a fraction of that amount.   Farm workers are paid about 40 cents per 32-pound bucket. The extra penny a pound would nearly double their pay to about 72 cents a bucket.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 08:30 ET (12:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: INTERVIEW: Dubai DIC Stake In HSBC Worth Around $1B - CEO -2
Story: "HSBC is an undervalued company, and it has great exposure to the emerging markets," Al Ansari said.   In April, Saudi Arabia-based investor Maan Abdul Wahed al-Sanea bought 3.11% in HSBC, according to a regulatory disclosure from the London Stock Exchange.   HSBC is an attractive asset for Middle Eastern investors such as DIC as "a value play within the banking sector," Morgan Stanley analyst David Williams said earlier this month. He added that the investment also helps diversify the portfolio at a time when the U.S. economy is slowing and the dollar weakening.   Al Ansari said DIC has earmarked $10 billion with the Global Strategic Equities Fund as part of a plan to buy shares in the world's leading 500 companies.   "We are investing in 10 companies with this fund, so each investment averages $1 billion," he said.   The fund is looking at six other Global-500 listed companies in the oil and gas sector, basic metals and consumer products, as well as a stake in European Aeronautic Defence & Space Co. NV, Al Ansari said.   "We are no closer to a deal with EADS today than three months ago," he said. "We are still doing due diligence."   DIC first revealed it was interested in taking a stake in the aircraft, helicopter and military equipment maker last year.   Al Ansari said DIC's deals have taken longer to complete than expected because stock prices are rising. "The stock markets have not been kind to us in the last few months," he said, adding that the first deal could be signed in the next four weeks.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 05:34 ET (09:34 GMT)

Headline: Skanska Argentina Chief Says Co Paid Undue Commissions Report
Story: BUENOS AIRES (Dow Jones)--The Argentine unit of Swedish engineering group Skanska AB (SKA-B.SK), paid undue commissions for the construction of a gas duct, the unit's head Hernan Morano confirmed to Argentine daily La Nacion in an interview published Saturday.   However, Moreno couldn't say whether those commissions amounted to bribery, as several local press reports suggested. "I can neither confirm it nor deny it. It's part of the past, we are going to investigate it," Moreno told la Nacion.   Moreno's remarks follow an investigation involving alleged kickbacks in a pipeline expansion project that Skanska carried out in 2005 on a subcontract from Transportadora de Gas del Norte SA (TGNO2.BA), which is controlled by Italian-Argentine Techint Group. Moreno took his job at the helm of Skanska Argentina at the beginning of 2006.   According to La Nacion, the budget for the gas duct project amounted to 11.7 million pesos ($3.8 million), on which Skanska paid undue commissions amounting to ARS13.4 million ($4.35 million), of which ARS7.7 million ($3.5 million) was reportedly audited by the company.   As part of the investigation, as many as seven former Skanska officials were arrested this month - as well as a Techint employee - on charges of tax evasion for unreported payments involved in the pipeline project. Meanwhile, a judge is investigating whether the unaccounted funds were used to bribe public officials.   Argentine President Nestor Kirchner and members of his cabinet initially said that no government officials were involved in any wrongdoing. But late this week, Kirchner fired two government officials who have been called to testify in court on the case, which risks damage to the government's image ahead of presidential elections due in October.   The dismissed officials are Fulvio Madaro, president of the natural gas regulatory group ENARGAS, and Nestor Alberto Ulloa, an official with the state-run bank Banco Nacion.     -By Serena Saitto, Dow Jones Newswires; 54911-53299040; serena.saitto@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 15:54 ET (19:54 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) An Empire Builder's Costly Legacy
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jay Palmer   The remark was ironic, though we didn't know it then. The occasion was a meeting in New York between two Barron's editors and Jurgen Schrempp nine years ago, around the time he was orchestrating Daimler's $36 billion acquisition of (or, as he at first insisted, "merger with") Chrysler. Mixing candor with self-deprecating humor and a burst of bombast, the dapper German quipped that he'd been one of the few executives -- perhaps the only one -- to lose his company a billiondollars and still keep his job.   Schrempp was referring to the deal he'd struck in the early '90s, as head of Daimler's aerospace division, to buy the Dutch airplane maker Fokker, a company he described as his "love child." Alas, Fokker went belly up a few years later, forcing Daimler to report the highest annual loss, to that point, of any German company since 1945. Despite that, Schrempp was appointed chief executive of Daimler within a year.   But the Fokker debacle was just a warmup.   A billion seems very small beer indeed alongside the $60 billion wiped off Daimler's market value under Schrempp's leadership -- or the $36 billion lost on Chrysler, not to mention some $3.5 billion that went down the drain through a failed alliance with Mitsubishi Motors (which was to be the Asian pillar of DaimlerChrysler's global behemoth, complementing Europe's Mercedes-Benz and America's Chrysler). And, of course, there are still further lakes of red ink from the ailing Smart Car, which Daimler finally is about to start selling in the U.S.   But perhaps the worst blow of all that Daimler suffered on Schrempp's watch was to Mercedes' quality, as engineering resources were shifted to Chrysler. The damage, which only now is being reversed, might have cost the company billions in unrealized sales as buyers, particularly in the U.S., purchased less-prestigious, less-enthralling but more reliable brands like Lexus.   At a later meeting in New York with Barron's, Schrempp said that despite his public statements to the contrary, he'd never meant the Daimler-Chrysler deal to be a marriage of equals, that from the very beginning Daimler was to be top dog. That remark, made also to the Financial Times, appeared in both publications. It figured in lawsuits from investor Kirk Kerkorian and other shareholders in the old Chrysler, who claimed they'd been misled. Result: expensive settlements.   Because the adjectives most often applied to Schrempp were "imperial" and "arrogant," the only really surprising thing is that he survived as long as he did in the CEO spot. When he did depart, in December 2005, there were no flowery company statements praising his 17 years at Daimler. There was also no pay for the final two years of his four-year contract or any golden parachute or severance package. (On this score, he fared far less well than ex-Chrysler Chairman Robert Eaton, who'd backed the deal with Daimler. He retired with more than $70 million in bonuses and options.)   The news of Schrempp's impending departure gave DaimlerChrysler stock its biggest one-day jump since before the merger. Since the announcement, the company's market value has gone from $53 billion to $88 billion. But for anyone who's held the stock for a decade, billions more will have to be added just to get back to its value in the pre-DaimlerChrysler era.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) Making The Most Of A -2-
Story: A: Pfizer is worth 34 easily, based on free cash flow. It is buying back a huge amount of stock and paying 20%-plus dividend increases. And they will be shoring up that product pipeline.     Q: Are you buying financials?   A: We are underweight financials. We like Bank of America [BAC] at 10 times earnings and 10% earnings growth, which is going to be very consistent over time, and a dividend yield of more than 4%. It's a very diversified financial company. Small-cap and mid-cap banks are generally overvalued at three times book value on average and 17 to 18 times earnings. A lot of them have 75% of their portfolio in residential real estate, which is a disaster waiting to happen. We are sticking with Fannie Mae [FNM] and Freddie Mac [FRE]. Those companies have lost market share over the last three or four years with all the new lenders coming onto the landscape. In the mortgage industry, the top 10 players hold about 60% of the business, and we think that is going to be further rationalized. The weaker players are going to be driven out of the business. Fannie and Freddie actually will benefit from the current problems in mortgage lending.     Q: Are there other overlooked opportunities?   A: Our consumer-staples position looks big but it's been primarily tobacco in the last 15 years. We thought Philip Morris was worth 105 back in 2001 when it sold at 19 a share with a 10% dividend yield. Now we are finally getting the value and the Kraft shares [KFT] were distributed at the end of March. People ask me if I like Kraft? At 18 times earnings with no growth, I can let you know we sold those shares. We are holding the Altria [MO] piece and expecting them to split Altria international and Altria domestic by year end probably. In that case, if you look at the whole pie, the tobacco company is clearly very underleveraged. They have no debt to speak of, and we expect they are going to be buying back stock. They are increasing dividends and might even pay a special dividend. We think the international piece is probably fully valued and the domestic piece looks undervalued. By year end, we might hold just the domestic piece, and that could bring our staples weighting down to maybe 5% from the high teens. That could be the end of an era for a Dreman portfolio, which has historically been overweight tobacco stocks.     Q: Thanks, Cliff.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) Streetwise: Drop-dead Beautiful Shares
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   Never mind the countless high-school yearbook quotations and the 150 million Google citations. Too much, eventually, is more than enough. And you can indeed have too much of a good thing. The trick is figuring out when the "good" goes too far for its own good.   The market's favorite good thing these days is the copious liquidity that's emboldening buyouts and levitating stocks. So much so that Merrill Lynch strategist Rich Bernstein challenged clients Friday to try to go a day without using the word "liquidity."   With leveraged-buyout loans running double last year's pace and Chrysler finding a private buyer and another $410 billion entering private-equity funds in the past year and Microsoft (ticker: MSFT) paying 78-times earnings and an 80% premium for (Who?) aQuantive (AQNT), surely we're in the silly phase, right? Well, probably not.   Just because everyone seems to believe the acquisition fever is in itself making stocks drop-dead attractive doesn't make it wrong -- yet.   The circumstantial evidence is pretty strong that stocks are taking their lead from the M&A calendar. This year, there has been at least one $5 billion-or-larger acquisition announced on 26 of the year's 95 trading days. On those 26 days, the single-day return for the Standard & Poor's 500 was more than double the average one-day return for the index this year.   Of course, this performance is coming in the context of a global asset lift, which has the U.S. market trundling near the rear. The S&P's 6.6% year-to-date rise compares with the 8.8% gain in the Dow Jones World ex-U.S. index, in dollar terms. The buyout binge is simply another reminder of easy cash and loose credit markets favoring risk assets.   Here's what to monitor as hints that the liquidity/buyout mania is entering its climactic absurdity phase.   First, the dealmakers will have to redefine huge. Yes, there have been a couple of $30 billion-plus LBOs announced in recent months. But the bell-ringing $30 billion purchase of RJR-Nabisco in 1988 would, in terms of today's market values, translate into something closer to $100 billion.   Premiums being paid for companies -- running in the 20% to 30% range -- would probably have to rise for the end to be nigh, suggests global-equity strategist Kevin Gardiner of HSBC. "The froth is yet to come," he insists.   The buyout guys might also begin chasing over-loved, market-leading, status-symbol companies before this game is up. Among  the 12 S&P 500 companies due to go private this year, there is plenty of dented and discarded merchandise, disdained by the Street -- Bausch & Lomb (BOL), Affiliated Computer Systems (ACS), Dollar General (DGO), Tribune (TRB) and SLM (SLM).   If history is to echo, then watch for company-on-company M&A action to get less and less rational. Most deals have lately been logical, if expensive, strategic moves. When the ill-conceived "transformative" tie-ups arrive -- those that meld disparate industries or rest on flimsy "2+2=5" logic -- move toward the exit.   More broadly, the global-liquidity bath continues to soothe and energize investors, but it's time to begin worrying that it might undermine itself. Monetary authorities are now viewing the free-and-easy investment backdrop with suspicion. More than one Fed official last week voiced worry over the mispricing of risk enabled by easy capital. Even the chairman of Bank of America said, "We are close to a time when we'll look back and say we did some stupid things."   Regulators and bank CEOs are usually good for more talk than action. And warnings about fatal excesses often precede any real pain by a long-enough stretch for the early warnings to have been forgotten (see: irrational exuberance).   But with junk-bond spreads over high-grade bonds back near lows seen just a handful of times in the past 20 years, the markets are not positioned to deal calmly with many adverse headlines -- whether some bureaucratic utterance from China about quelling speculation, or a failed LBO financing.   So, enjoy the deal-a-week lottery and the Friday rumor game and resilient ticker tape. Just realize that looking for huge upside here involves riding the pendulum from the rational to the silly, without a clear idea where the border lies.   On a shorter-term basis, of course, stocks are well stretched after their two-month sprint. The public isn't yet giddy for stocks, but the pros feel pretty bulletproof, say a few sentiment measures. The mega-cap leadership in recent weeks, including the recent revival of laggards General Electric (GE) and Citigroup (C) could mean the rally is in a mature phase. These two stocks also popped in late December as the market was about to flatten. Watch for the report late Monday on NYSE short interest to see whether the naysayers have finally retreated.   ---   e-mail: michael.santoli@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Singapore Temasek Holdings Fails In Stats Privatization Bid
Story: SINGAPORE (Dow Jones)--Singapore government investment firm Temasek Holdings Pte Ltd. (TEMAH.YY) has failed in its privatization bid for chip tester Stats Chippac Ltd. (S24.SG) but will have control of the company.   Temasek got acceptances from shareholders that bring its stake in Stats to 83.1%, shortof the 90.0% needed to take the company private, Temasek said in a statement Friday.   Valuing Stats at S$3.57 billion, Temasek in March offered S$1.75 a share conditional on minimum acceptances of half of the 64.4% of Stats shares it didn't own. The offer would have gone up to S$1.88 a share if acceptances crossed 90%.   Temasek didn't reach the threshold to prompt a mandatory delisting, but it has effective control of Stats.   Temasek has said it may seek to delist Stats by calling for a general meeting and shareholder vote.   If Temasek submits a delisting proposal to the exchange, it must make an offer to investors that didn't participate in the original offer at a price of S$1.75 per share or less.     -By Vladimir Guevarra and John Jannarone, Dow Jones Newswires; +65 6415 4155; +65 6415 4152; vladimir.guevarra@dowjones.com; john.jannarone@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 03:09 ET (07:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Saudi Aramco Extends Ras Tanura Refinery Maintenance
Story: (Update with details on maintenance work period and more quotes)     RIYADH (Zawya Dow Jones)--Saudi Arabian Oil Co., the world's largest oil company by production, said Saturday it will extend the regular maintenance at its Ras Tanura refinery on the Persian Gulf coast by almost three weeks.   "Due to technical reasons, Saudi Aramco decided to extend the period of regular maintenance in Ras Tanura refinery until June 8," the company said in a statement to state-run news agency SPA.   An Aramco official said the maintenance started April 24 and it related to the asphalt unit.   However, Aramco spokesman Ziyad Al Shihah said in the release that the company remained committed to meeting domestic asphalt demand.   Ras Tanura produces 17,000 barrels a day of asphalt, a third of the total asphalt produced in four of Aramco's five domestic refineries, according to the statement.   "We have increased production level in other refineries to replace Ras Tanura output of asphalt supplies. The company will be working to finalize maintenance work before May 8," one official told Zawya Dow Jones by phone.   The refinery, the kingdom's most complex, has capacity to process 550,000 barrels a day of refined products.   Aramco and the U.S. Dow Chemical Co. signed a memorandum of understanding on May 12 to integrate the facility it with a large-scale petrochemicals complex.   -By Anees Al Qudaihi, Dow Jones Newswires, +966 1 2914872, anees.alqudaihi@dowjones.com   Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 08:08 ET (12:08 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(5/21) Plugged In: Will Nokia Break TI's Heart?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   It looks like Nokia wants to cool off its serious relationship with Texas Instruments and start dating other chip suppliers. This isn't a new phenomenon.   First, Motorola weaned itself from its former semiconductor unit, Freescale Semiconductor, by launching a relationship with Qualcomm (Plugged In, Feb. 20, 2006). Then, in February, Nokia (ticker: NOK) announced that Germany's Infineon Technologies would provide a single-chip platform for its entry-level handsets in emerging markets like India and China. Texas Instruments (TXN), also known as TI, has been a near-exclusive supplier of power management and baseband chips -- the brains for wireless handsets -- to Nokia. But it appears that the Infineon deal was only the first blow.   Now there's speculation that Nokia is turning to the likes of Freescale and Broadcom to serve as alternative chip suppliers for higher-end handsets at the expense of TI. A Freescale spokesperson would not comment on Nokia. TI's Director of Investor Relations David Pahl also wouldn't comment on Nokia's decisions but said that the company is aware of handset makers opting to use multiple chip suppliers. The trend, he said, could net more business for TI than it loses, pointing to new business that it recently won from Motorola (MOT).   At Broadcom (BRCM), Chief Exec Scott McGregor could barely keep his lips sealed in a recent conference call. The speculation is that Broadcom will win 2.5G, or Edge, phone business and perhaps some 3G business. (2.5G, which is the latest network technology based on second-generation networks allowing data transmission, isn't as powerful as the newer 3G.) Broadcom grew by supplying chips to the cable-TV industry, but it's determined to crack into wireless communications. "In 2007, our goal is to win designs. In 2008, you should start seeing products come out, and 2009 has to be all about gain in market share," McGregor told analysts and investors. "You'll see some other products come out later in the year, [but] I can't say too much about them," he said.   Engineering mobile-handset platforms is complex and time-consuming. And much of that work needs to be done with the chip makers. Then it seems to take forever for the handset makers to spill the beans. It took about a year for Motorola to disclose the news about Freescale after my first column on it. It could be months before we get official word on Nokia's intentions.   "We won't be able to announce those design wins as they happen, which is, I assure you, as frustrating for you as it is for us -- but that's the nature of that business," McGregor said. As products come out in 2008, there should be more to talk about, he said. Nokia doesn't comment on supplier relationships.   Chances are that Nokia will divert some of its high-end phone-chip deals to others, whether it's Freescale, Broadcom, both or some other firm. Regardless, it's clear competition in the wireless sector is red-hot and that incumbents, such as TI, could lose share, possibly setting off a margin-crunching price war.   TI shares have been on a tear since beating earnings and raising expectations in April. They are up more than 35% from their July 2006 low. In the interim, the company has been plying investors with forecasts of fatter profit margins. What's interesting is that TI's chatter has focused on its lower-end analog-chip business, not its wireless semiconductors. If what we're hearing is true, a price war in wireless won't help TI hit those lofty margin goals.   ---   E-mail: mark.veverka@barrons.com   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Xinhua Finance Board Announcement
Story: SHANGHAI, May 19 /Xinhua-PRNewswire/ -- Xinhua Finance Ltd. (TSE: 9399) (OTC ADRs: XHFNY) and Xinhua Finance Media (Nasdaq: XFML) announced today that Mr. Shelly Singhal has resigned from the Boards of both companies, as well as from all executive and managerial positions.  His departure is immediate.     "Mr. Singhal provided important assistance throughout the development of Xinhua Finance Ltd. and Xinhua Finance Media," commented Chairman and CEO Fredy Bush, "He remains a strong supporter of both companies, and he has our thanks for his tireless efforts in contributing to our successes to date."     "It is a difficult decision to leave these two companies that I have helped to grow.  Unfortunately, recent allegations against me in the press concerning my activities prior to joining Xinhua Finance have created a situation where my continued involvement with Xinhua Finance has become a distraction to management, so it is clearly the right thing to do now," Mr. Singhal commented.  "There is a deep pool of entrepreneurial and managerial talent in place to insure continued progress.  I remain a loyal and long-term follower and shareholder, and wish the two companies well."     Mr. Singhal is currently the subject of a civil suit which is unrelated to Xinhua Finance.  Mr. Singhal has advised that he believes this claim to be without merit and that he intends to dispute it vigorously.     Fredy Bush added, "We wish Shelly the best and are grateful to him for his efforts on behalf of Xinhua Finance.  During his time with Xinhua Finance, we believe Shelly has conducted himself with integrity and professionalism.  In the meantime, we look forward to putting this matter behind us and focusing on what we do best-continuing to build our business in China and creating value for our shareholders".        About the companies Xinhua Finance Limited     Xinhua Finance Limited is China's premier financial information and media service provider and is listed on the Mothers Board of the Tokyo Stock Exchange (symbol: 9399) (OTC ADRs: XHFNY). Bridging China's financial markets and the world, Xinhua Finance serves financial institutions, corporations and re-distributors through five focused and complementary service lines: Indices, Ratings, Financial News, Investor Relations, and Distribution.  Founded in November 1999, the Company is headquartered in Shanghai, with offices and news bureaus spanning 14 countries worldwide.        For more information, please visit www.xinhuafinance.com.        About Xinhua Finance Media Limited     Xinhua Finance Media ("XFMedia"; Nasdaq: XFML) is China's leading diversified financial and entertainment media company targeting high net worth individuals nationwide. The company reaches its target audience via TV, radio, newspapers, magazines and other distribution channels. Through its five synergistic business groups, Advertising, Broadcast, Print, Production and Research, XFMedia offers a total solution empowering clients at every stage of the media process and keeping people connected and entertained.     Headquartered in Beijing, the company has offices and affiliates in major cities of China including Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Shenzhen and Hong Kong.        For more information, please visit www.xinhuafinancemedia.com.        Safe Harbor Statement     This announcement contains forward-looking statements. These statements are made under the "safe harbor" provisions of the U.S. Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements can be identified by terminology such as "will," "expects," "anticipates," "future," "intends," "plans," "believes," "estimates," "confident" and similar statements. Among other things, quotations from management in this announcement contain forward-looking statements. XFMedia may also make written or oral forward-looking statements in its periodic reports to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on forms 20-F and 6-K, etc., in its annual report to shareholders, in press releases and other written materials and in oral statements made by its officers, directors or employees to third parties. Statements that are not historical facts, including statements about XFMedia's beliefs and expectations, are forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements involve inherent risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in any forward-looking statements. Headline: INTERVIEW: Dubai DIC Stake In HSBC Worth Around $1B - CEO
Story: By Ayesha Daya   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     DEAD SEA, Jordan (Dow Jones)--Dubai International Capital invested around $1 billion in its recently acquired stake in HSBC Holdings PLC, the Dubai government-owned company's chief executive said Saturday.   "We took a substantial amount," Sameer Al Ansari told Dow Jones Newswires in an interview on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in the Jordanian Dead Sea resort.   The Dubai firm, which is controlled by the emirate's rulers, said earlier this month it bought the HSBC stake through its $2-billion Global Strategic Equities Fund.   The exact size and value of the stake has not been disclosed, but under U.K. market rules, a stake would have to be declared if it exceeded 3%.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 05:14 ET (09:14 GMT)

Headline: Amtek Engineering In Takeover Talks With New Parties
Story: SINGAPORE (Dow Jones)--The board of Singapore's Amtek Engineering Ltd. (A11.SG) has been approached by new parties regarding a possible takeover, and one of the unnamed parties has gained due diligence access to the company, Amtek said in a statement Friday.   The expanded talks follow a May 15 announcement that another party approached Amtek shareholders and also received due diligence access from the board.   The diversified electronics manufacturer has hired a financial adviser to assist its board, but no other details were given.     -By John Jannarone, Dow Jones Newswires; 65 6415 4152; john.jannarone@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 03:58 ET (07:58 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/21) Barron's Mailbag: iMergent Bull Emerges
Story: (From BARRON'S)   To the Editor:     Neil Martin's article about iMergent ("What the Press Release Won't Say," May 7) was a total hatchet job. Like many others, he is a pawn in the larger scheme that short sellers have been plotting for the past two years.   The company has received a clean bill of health from every attorney general and is allowed to do business in their jurisdictions. The Utah ruling is immaterial because it would only apply in Utah, and the company has no seminars in Utah.   The prior companies that CEO Donald L. Danks was involved with went bankrupt several years after he left them.   The company has the most conservative accounting method -- cash for revenue and accrual for expenses. Yet even with that treatment, it has posted incredible results.   On March 27, the company revised its growth rate for the quarter and year. It was then that the 50% number was first mentioned, not in phone calls.   The only inside information that was traded on was that Barron's was going to do a hatchet job on iMergent. Trading in put options was significant.   Your unidentified source who was told what the earnings would be was also dubious. This individual presented himself in a questionable manner and used that to obtain information. I have known Danks for over three years, and I have never been told any inside information by him.   Alan Weichselbaum   Lawrence, N.Y.     Neil Martin replies: As a holder of the stock, Mr. Weichselbaum should be concerned about future negative actions by state attorneys general against iMergent -- especially in Utah and Florida -- but even more troubled by the company's tendency not to reveal them. For example, the company received a "cease and desist" order from North Carolina last October, but didn't disclose it to shareholders until this month and then only via a discrete SEC filing, rather than a press release.   As for the reliability of our source, the company on May 7 announced exactly the non-GAAP earnings and revenue we reported May 5. Neither iMergent nor Donald L. Danks has denied that the information was leaked prematurely. Also, the company hadn't publicly given guidance on its earnings-growth rate, only on revenue projections. Shareholders read it first in Barron's.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 19, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
